(nominal)">62nd</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-pol-div-fake-li">\xe2\x80\xa2&#160;Per capita</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span typeof="mw:File"><span title="Increase"><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300" /></span></span> $37,093<sup id="cite_ref-IMFWEO.PR_25-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEO.PR-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">28th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a>&#160;<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"><span class="nobold">(2024)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">58<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><br /><span class="nowrap"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239334494">@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output div:not(.notheme)>.tmp-color,html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output p>.tmp-color,html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output table:not(.notheme) .tmp-color{color:inherit!important}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output div:not(.notheme)>.tmp-color,html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output p>.tmp-color,html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output table:not(.notheme) .tmp-color{color:inherit!important}}</style><span class="tmp-color" style="color:darkred">high</span></span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a>&#160;<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"><span class="nobold">(2015)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">0.845<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><br /><span class="nowrap"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239334494"><span class="tmp-color" style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span>&#160;\xc2\xb7&#160;<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">40th</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">United States dollar</a> (US$) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">USD</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Time_zone" title="Time zone">Time zone</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/UTC-04:00" class="mw-redirect" title="UTC-04:00">UTC-04:00</a> (<a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Time_Zone" title="Atlantic Time Zone">AST</a>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data">dd/mm/yyyy<br />mm/dd/yyyy</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Telephone numbers in Puerto Rico">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Telephone numbers in Puerto Rico">+1 (787), +1 (939)</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/USPS_abbreviation" class="mw-redirect" title="USPS abbreviation">USPS abbreviation</a></span></th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="postal-code">PR</div></td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><div class="hlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:PR" title="ISO 3166-2:PR">PR</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:US" title="ISO 3166-2:US">US-PR</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.pr" title=".pr">.pr</a></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p><span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><b>Puerto Rico</b><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>i<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span></span> (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> for &#39;rich port&#39;; abbreviated <b>PR</b>),<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> officially the <b>Commonwealth of Puerto Rico</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-commonwealth_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-commonwealth-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>j<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Government of Puerto Rico">self-governing</a> <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Geography of Puerto Rico">archipelago and island</a> organized as an <a href="/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States" title="Territories of the United States">unincorporated territory</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> under the designation of <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_(U.S._insular_area)" title="Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)">commonwealth</a>. Located about 1,000 miles (1,600&#160;km) southeast of <a href="/wiki/Miami,_Florida" class="mw-redirect" title="Miami, Florida">Miami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a>, between the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Antilles" title="Greater Antilles">Greater Antilles</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands" title="United States Virgin Islands">U.S. Virgin Islands</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Antilles" title="Lesser Antilles">Lesser Antilles</a>, it consists of the <a href="/wiki/Eponym" title="Eponym">eponymous</a> main island and numerous smaller islands, including <a href="/wiki/Vieques,_Puerto_Rico" title="Vieques, Puerto Rico">Vieques</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culebra,_Puerto_Rico" title="Culebra, Puerto Rico">Culebra</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_Mona" title="Isla de Mona">Mona</a>. With approximately 3.2&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans" title="Puerto Ricans">residents</a>, it is divided into <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Municipalities of Puerto Rico">78 municipalities</a>, of which the most populous is the <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital</a> municipality of <a href="/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico" title="San Juan, Puerto Rico">San Juan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Official_languages" class="mw-redirect" title="Official languages">official languages</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch_of_the_government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Executive branch of the government of Puerto Rico">executive branch</a> of <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Government of Puerto Rico">government</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though Spanish predominates.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico was settled by a succession of peoples beginning 2,000 to 4,000 years ago;<sup id="cite_ref-Taus-Bolstad2004_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taus-Bolstad2004-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> these included the <a href="/wiki/Ortoiroid_people" title="Ortoiroid people">Ortoiroid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saladoid" title="Saladoid">Saladoid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Ta\xc3\xadno">Ta\xc3\xadno</a>. It was claimed by <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spain</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus" title="Voyages of Christopher Columbus">arrival</a> of <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> in 1493 and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">colonization</a>  by <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ponce de Le\xc3\xb3n">Juan Ponce de Le\xc3\xb3n</a> in 1508.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico was contested by other European <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">powers</a>, but remained a Spanish possession for the next four centuries. An influx of <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_Spanish_New_World_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavery in the Spanish New World colonies">African slaves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spaniard</a> settlers, primarily from the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>, vastly changed the cultural and demographic landscape of the island. Within the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a>, Puerto Rico played a secondary but strategic role compared to wealthier colonies like <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru" title="Viceroyalty of Peru">Peru</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">New Spain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By the late 19th century, a distinct Puerto Rican identity began to emerge, centered around a fusion of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">indigenous</a>, <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">European</a> elements.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1898, following the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War">Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War</a>, Puerto Rico was <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">acquired by the United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans" title="Puerto Ricans">Puerto Ricans</a> have been <a href="/wiki/United_States_nationality_law" title="United States nationality law">U.S. citizens</a> since 1917, and can move freely between the island and the <a href="/wiki/Contiguous_United_States" title="Contiguous United States">mainland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Puerto Ricans who do not reside in a <a href="/wiki/U.S._state" title="U.S. state">U.S. state</a> are <a href="/wiki/Federal_voting_rights_in_Puerto_Rico#Disenfranchisement_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Federal voting rights in Puerto Rico">disenfranchised from federal elections</a><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and generally do not pay <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Taxation in Puerto Rico">federal income tax</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>k<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In common with four other territories, Puerto Rico sends a <a href="/wiki/Nonvoting_members_of_Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="Nonvoting members of Congress">nonvoting representative</a> to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Congress">U.S. Congress</a>, called a <a href="/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico">Resident Commissioner</a>, and participates in <a href="/wiki/2020_Puerto_Rico_presidential_primaries" title="2020 Puerto Rico presidential primaries">presidential primaries</a>; as it is not a state, Puerto Rico does not have a vote in the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Congress">U.S. Congress</a>, which governs it under the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Federal_Relations_Act_of_1950" title="Puerto Rico Federal Relations Act of 1950">Puerto Rico Federal Relations Act of 1950</a>. Congress approved <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Constitution of Puerto Rico">a local constitution</a> in 1952, allowing U.S. citizens residing on the island to elect <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Governor of Puerto Rico">a governor</a>. Puerto Rico\'s <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Political status of Puerto Rico">current and future political status</a> has consistently been a matter of significant debate.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Beginning in the mid-20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">U.S. government</a>, together with the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Industrial_Development_Company" title="Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company">Puerto Rico Industrial Development Company</a>, launched a series of economic projects to develop Puerto Rico into an industrial high-income economy. It is classified by the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed jurisdiction</a> with an advanced, <a href="/wiki/High-income_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="High-income economy">high-income economy</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Advanced_economies_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Advanced_economies-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> it ranks 40th on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. The major sectors of Puerto Rico\'s economy are <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Manufacturing in Puerto Rico">manufacturing</a> (primarily <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Pharmaceutical industry in Puerto Rico">pharmaceuticals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petrochemical" title="Petrochemical">petrochemicals</a>, and electronics) followed by <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">services</a> (namely <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Tourism in Puerto Rico">tourism</a> and hospitality).<sup id="cite_ref-manufacturing-by-pr.gov_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-manufacturing-by-pr.gov-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Etymology">Etymology</h2></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico is Spanish for "rich port".<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican people">Puerto Ricans</a> often call the island <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Borinquen</i></span>, a derivation of <span title="Taino-language text"><i lang="tnq">Borik\xc3\xa9n</i></span>, its <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">indigenous</a> <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Ta\xc3\xadno">Ta\xc3\xadno</a> name, which is popularly said to mean "Land of the Valiant Lord".<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The terms <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">boricua</i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">borinque\xc3\xb1o</i></span>, and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">borincano</i></span> are commonly used to identify someone of Puerto Rican heritage,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and derive from <span title="Taino-language text"><i lang="tnq">Borik\xc3\xa9n</i></span> and <span title="Taino-language text"><i lang="tnq">Borinquen</i></span> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The island is also popularly known in Spanish as <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">La Isla del Encanto</i></span>, meaning "the island of enchantment".<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Columbus named the island <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">San Juan Bautista</i></span>, in honor of Saint <a href="/wiki/John_the_Baptist" title="John the Baptist">John the Baptist</a>, while the capital city was named <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Ciudad de Puerto Rico</i></span> ("Rich Port City").<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Eventually traders and other maritime visitors came to refer to the entire island as Puerto Rico, while San Juan became the name used for the main trading/shipping port and the capital city.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>l<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The island\'s name was changed to <i>Porto Rico</i> by the United States after the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_of_1898" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Paris of 1898">Treaty of Paris of 1898</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The anglicized name was used by the U.S. government and private enterprises (also <i>Porto</i> in Italian, French, and Portuguese). The name was changed back to Puerto Rico in 1931 by a joint resolution in Congress introduced by <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_C%C3%B3rdova_D%C3%A1vila" title="F\xc3\xa9lix C\xc3\xb3rdova D\xc3\xa1vila">F\xc3\xa9lix C\xc3\xb3rdova D\xc3\xa1vila</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>m<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The official name of the entity in Spanish is <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Estado_Libre_Asociado_de_Puerto_Rico" title="Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico">Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico</a></i></span> ("Free <a href="/wiki/Associated_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Associated State">Associated State</a> of Puerto Rico"), while its official English name is <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_(U.S._insular_area)#Commonwealth_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)">Commonwealth of Puerto Rico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico_30-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook_-_Puerto_Rico-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236091366">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}html.client-js body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}</style><table class="box-Expand_section plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="[icon]" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="14" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="44" data-file-height="31" /></a></span></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs expansion</b>. You can help by <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">adding to it</a>.  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2024</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Puerto_Rico" title="History of Puerto Rico">History of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Taino_Village.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Taino_Village.JPG/220px-Taino_Village.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Taino_Village.JPG/330px-Taino_Village.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Taino_Village.JPG/440px-Taino_Village.JPG 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480" /></a><figcaption>A 20th-century reconstruction of an 8th-century <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Ta\xc3\xadno">Ta\xc3\xadno</a> village, located at the <a href="/wiki/Tibes_Indigenous_Ceremonial_Center" title="Tibes Indigenous Ceremonial Center">spot</a> in which their remains were discovered in 1975, in the aftermath of <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Eloise" title="Hurricane Eloise">Hurricane Eloise</a><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg/290px-Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="193" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg/435px-Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg/580px-Puerto_Rico_departamentos_1886.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2250" data-file-height="1494" /></a><figcaption>Map of the <a href="/wiki/Department_(country_subdivision)" class="mw-redirect" title="Department (country subdivision)">departments</a> of Puerto Rico during Spanish provincial times (1886).</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The history of Puerto Rico began with the settlement of the <a href="/wiki/Ortoiroid_people" title="Ortoiroid people">Ortoiroid people</a> before 430 BC. At the time of <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a>\'s arrival in the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a> in 1493, the dominant indigenous culture was that of the <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADnos" class="mw-redirect" title="Ta\xc3\xadnos">Ta\xc3\xadnos</a>. The Ta\xc3\xadno people\'s numbers went dangerously low during the later half of the 16th century because of new infectious diseases carried by Europeans, exploitation by Spanish settlers, and warfare.<sup id="cite_ref-Diseases_carried_by_Europeans_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diseases_carried_by_Europeans-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Located in the northeastern Caribbean, Puerto Rico formed a key part of the Spanish Empire from the early years of the exploration, conquest and colonization of the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>. The island was a major military post during many wars between Spain and other European powers for control of the region in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.\n</p><p>In 1593, Portuguese soldiers, sent from Lisbon by order of Phillip II, composed the first garrison of the San Felipe del Morro fortress in Puerto Rico. Some brought their wives, while others married Puerto Rican women, and today there are many Puerto Rican families with Portuguese last names. The smallest of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Antilles" title="Greater Antilles">Greater Antilles</a>, Puerto Rico was a stepping-stone in the passage from Europe to Cuba, Mexico, Central America, and the northern territories of South America. Throughout most of the 19th century until the conclusion of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War">Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War</a>, Puerto Rico and Cuba were the last two Spanish colonies in the New World; they served as Spain\'s final outposts in a strategy to regain control of the American continents. Realizing that it was in danger of losing its two remaining Caribbean territories, the Spanish Crown revived the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Decree_of_Graces_of_1815" title="Royal Decree of Graces of 1815">Royal Decree of Graces of 1815</a>. The decree was printed in Spanish, English and French in order to attract Europeans, with the hope that the independence movements would lose their popularity and strength with the arrival of new settlers. Free land was offered to those who wanted to populate the islands on the condition that they swear their loyalty to the Spanish Crown and allegiance to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Graces_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Graces-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1898, during the Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War, Puerto Rico was invaded and subsequently became a possession of the U.S. The first years of the 20th century were marked by the struggle to obtain greater democratic rights from the U.S.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Foraker_Act" title="Foraker Act">Foraker Act</a> of 1900 established a civil government, ending <a href="/wiki/List_of_governors_of_Puerto_Rico#Military_government" title="List of governors of Puerto Rico">rule by American generals</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_War#1898\xe2\x80\x931939" title="United States Department of War">Department of War</a>.  A <a href="/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Supreme Court">U.S. Supreme Court</a> ruling, <i>Ortega v. Lara</i>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_202" title="List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 202">202</a>&#32;<a href="/wiki/United_States_Reports" title="United States Reports">U.S.</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/202/339/#342">339, 342</a>&#32;(1906),<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>n<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> involving the Foraker Act and referring to the island as "the acquired country", soon affirmed that the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Constitution">U.S. Constitution</a> applied within its territory and that any domestic Puerto Rican laws which did not conflict with it remained in force.<sup id="cite_ref-DerechoPuertorrique\xc3\xb1o_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DerechoPuertorrique\xc3\xb1o-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Jones-Shafroth_Act" class="mw-redirect" title="Jones-Shafroth Act">Jones Act</a> of 1917, which made Puerto Ricans <a href="/wiki/United_States_citizenship" class="mw-redirect" title="United States citizenship">U.S. citizens</a>, paved the way for the drafting of <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Constitution of Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico\'s Constitution</a> and its approval by Congress and Puerto Rican voters in 1952. However, the political status of Puerto Rico, a <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_(U.S._insular_area)" title="Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)">Commonwealth</a> controlled by the U.S., remains an anomaly.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="21st_century">21st century</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Proposed_political_status_for_Puerto_Rico" title="Proposed political status for Puerto Rico">Proposed political status for Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Task_Force_on_Puerto_Rico%27s_Status" title="President&#39;s Task Force on Puerto Rico&#39;s Status">President\'s Task Force on Puerto Rico\'s Status</a></div>\n<p>In 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Special_Committee_on_Decolonization" title="Special Committee on Decolonization">United Nations Special Committee on Decolonization</a> approved a draft resolution calling on the U.S. government to expedite a process that would allow the Puerto Rican people to exercise fully their inalienable right to self-determination and independence.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In November 2012, a two-question referendum took place, simultaneous with the general elections.<sup id="cite_ref-oslpr1_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oslpr1-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The first question, voted on in August, asked voters whether they wanted to maintain the current status under the territorial clause of the U.S. Constitution. 54% voted against the status quo, effectively approving the second question to be voted on in November. The second question posed three alternate status options: statehood, independence, or <a href="/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association" title="Compact of Free Association">free association</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 61.16% voted for statehood, 33.34% for a sovereign free-associated state, and 5.49% for independence.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (June 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>In 2016, President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> signed into law <i>H.R. 5278: <a href="/wiki/PROMESA" title="PROMESA">PROMESA</a></i>, establishing a Control Board over the Puerto Rican government. This board will have a significant degree of federal control involved in its establishment and operations. In particular, the authority to establish the control board derives from the federal government\'s constitutional power to "make all needful rules and regulations" regarding U.S. territories; The president would appoint all seven voting members of the board; and the board would have broad sovereign powers to effectively overrule decisions by Puerto Rico\'s legislature, governor, and other public authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico held its <a href="/wiki/2020_Puerto_Rican_status_referendum" title="2020 Puerto Rican status referendum">statehood referendum</a> during the 3 November 2020 general elections; the ballot asked one question: "Should Puerto Rico be admitted immediately into the Union <a href="/wiki/51st_state" title="51st state">as a State</a>?" The results showed that 52 percent of Puerto Rico voters answered yes.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Geography">Geography</h2></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Geography of Puerto Rico">Geography of Puerto Rico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Geology of Puerto Rico">Geology of Puerto Rico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Puerto_Rico" title="List of islands of Puerto Rico">List of islands of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg/220px-Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg/330px-Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg/440px-Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a><figcaption>Beach and coastline at <a href="/wiki/Patillas,_Puerto_Rico" title="Patillas, Puerto Rico">Patillas</a>, in southeast Puerto Rico</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rico consists of the main island of Puerto Rico and various smaller islands, including <a href="/wiki/Vieques,_Puerto_Rico" title="Vieques, Puerto Rico">Vieques</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culebra,_Puerto_Rico" title="Culebra, Puerto Rico">Culebra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mona,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Mona, Puerto Rico">Mona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desecheo_Island" title="Desecheo Island">Desecheo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Caja_de_Muertos,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Caja de Muertos, Puerto Rico">Caja de Muertos</a>. Of these five, only Culebra and Vieques are inhabited year-round. Mona, which has played a key role in maritime history, is uninhabited most of the year except for employees of the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Natural_and_Environmental_Resources_(Puerto_Rico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of Natural and Environmental Resources (Puerto Rico)">Puerto Rico Department of Natural Resources</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are many other even smaller <a href="/wiki/Islets" class="mw-redirect" title="Islets">islets</a>, like <a href="/wiki/Monito_Island" title="Monito Island">Monito</a>, located near Mona,<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Isla_de_Cabras" title="Isla de Cabras">Isla de Cabras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isleta_de_San_Juan" class="mw-redirect" title="Isleta de San Juan">La Isleta de San Juan</a>, both located on the <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Bay" title="San Juan Bay">San Juan Bay</a>. The latter is the only inhabited islet with communities like <a href="/wiki/Old_San_Juan" title="Old San Juan">Old San Juan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puerta_de_Tierra" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerta de Tierra">Puerta de Tierra</a>, which are connected to the main island by bridges.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_(2020).png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png/220px-NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="96" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png/330px-NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png/440px-NOAA_Bathymetry_Image_of_Puerto_Rico_%282020%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1702" data-file-height="743" /></a><figcaption>NOAA Bathymetry Image of Puerto Rico (2020)<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<p>The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has an area of 5,320 square miles (13,800&#160;km<sup>2</sup>), of which 3,420&#160;sq&#160;mi (8,900&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) is land and 1,900&#160;sq&#160;mi (4,900&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) is water.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico is larger than <a href="/wiki/Delaware" title="Delaware">Delaware</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island" title="Rhode Island">Rhode Island</a> but smaller than <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>. The maximum length of the main island from east to west is 110&#160;mi (180&#160;km), and the maximum width from north to south is 40&#160;mi (64&#160;km).<sup id="cite_ref-topuertorico.com_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-topuertorico.com-87"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico is the smallest of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Antilles" title="Greater Antilles">Greater Antilles</a>. It is 80% of the size of <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> just over 18% of the size of <a href="/wiki/Hispaniola" title="Hispaniola">Hispaniola</a> and 8% of the size of Cuba, the largest of the Greater Antilles.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>\nThe topography of the island is mostly mountainous with large flat areas in the northern and southern coasts. The main mountain range that crosses the island from east to west is called the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Central_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Cordillera Central (Puerto Rico)">Cordillera Central</a> (also known as the Central Mountain Range in English). The highest elevation in Puerto Rico, <a href="/wiki/Cerro_de_Punta" title="Cerro de Punta">Cerro de Punta</a> 4,390 feet (1,340&#160;m),<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is located in this range. Another important peak is <a href="/wiki/El_Yunque,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="El Yunque, Puerto Rico">El Yunque</a>, one of the highest in the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_de_Luquillo" title="Sierra de Luquillo">Sierra de Luquillo</a> at the <a href="/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest" title="El Yunque National Forest">El Yunque National Forest</a>, with an elevation of 3,494&#160;ft (1,065&#160;m).<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Highways,_Primary,_Secondary,_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg/220px-Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="106" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg/330px-Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg/440px-Map_of_Highways%2C_Primary%2C_Secondary%2C_Tertiary_Routes_in_Puerto_Rico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3564" data-file-height="1724" /></a><figcaption>Map by USGIS</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rico has 17 lakes, all man-made, and more than <a href="/wiki/List_of_Puerto_Rico_rivers" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Puerto Rico rivers">50 rivers</a>, most of which originate in the Cordillera Central.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Rivers in the northern region of the island are typically longer and of higher <a href="/wiki/Volumetric_flow_rate" title="Volumetric flow rate">water flow rates</a> than those of the south, since the south receives less rain than the central and northern regions.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico is composed of <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> to <a href="/wiki/Eocene" title="Eocene">Eocene</a> <a href="/wiki/Volcanic" class="mw-redirect" title="Volcanic">volcanic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Plutonic" class="mw-redirect" title="Plutonic">plutonic</a> rocks, overlain by younger <a href="/wiki/Oligocene" title="Oligocene">Oligocene</a> and more recent <a href="/wiki/Carbonate" title="Carbonate">carbonates</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Sedimentary_rocks" class="mw-redirect" title="Sedimentary rocks">sedimentary rocks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most of the <a href="/wiki/Caverns" class="mw-redirect" title="Caverns">caverns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">karst</a> topography on the island occurs in the northern region. The oldest rocks are approximately <span class="nowrap">190 million</span> years old (<a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a>) and are located at <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Bermeja" title="Sierra Bermeja">Sierra Bermeja</a> in the southwest part of the island. They may represent part of the <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust">oceanic crust</a> and are believed to come from the Pacific Ocean realm.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico lies at the boundary between the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Plate" title="Caribbean Plate">Caribbean</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plates</a> and is being deformed by the <a href="/wiki/Tectonics" title="Tectonics">tectonic</a> stresses caused by their interaction. These stresses may cause <a href="/wiki/Earthquakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthquakes">earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunamis</a>. These <a href="/wiki/Seismic" class="mw-redirect" title="Seismic">seismic</a> events, along with <a href="/wiki/Landslide" title="Landslide">landslides</a>, represent some of the most dangerous <a href="/wiki/Geologic_hazards" class="mw-redirect" title="Geologic hazards">geologic hazards</a> in the island and in the northeastern Caribbean. The <a href="/wiki/1918_San_Ferm%C3%ADn_earthquake" title="1918 San Ferm\xc3\xadn earthquake">1918 San Ferm\xc3\xadn earthquake</a> occurred on <span class="nowrap">11 October</span>, 1918 and had an estimated magnitude of 7.5 on the <a href="/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale" class="mw-redirect" title="Richter magnitude scale">Richter scale</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1918_quake_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1918_quake-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It originated off the coast of <a href="/wiki/Aguadilla" class="mw-redirect" title="Aguadilla">Aguadilla</a>, several kilometers off the northern coast, and was accompanied by a <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunami</a>. It caused extensive property damage and widespread losses, damaging infrastructure, especially bridges. It resulted in an estimated 116 deaths and $4&#160;million in property damage. The failure of the government to move rapidly to provide for the general welfare contributed to political activism by opponents and eventually to the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Nationalist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican Nationalist Party">Puerto Rican Nationalist Party</a>. On 7 January 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the country experienced <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Puerto_Rico_earthquakes" title="2019\xe2\x80\x9320 Puerto Rico earthquakes">its largest earthquake</a> since 1918,<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> estimated at magnitude 6.4.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Economic losses were estimated to be more than $3.1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Trench" title="Puerto Rico Trench">Puerto Rico Trench</a>, the largest and deepest trench in the Atlantic, is located about 71&#160;mi (114&#160;km) north of Puerto Rico at the boundary between the Caribbean and North American plates.<sup id="cite_ref-trench_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trench-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is 170&#160;mi (270&#160;km) long.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At its deepest point, named the <a href="/wiki/Milwaukee_Deep" title="Milwaukee Deep">Milwaukee Deep</a>, it is almost 27,600&#160;ft (8,400&#160;m) deep.<sup id="cite_ref-trench_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trench-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mona_Canyon" title="Mona Canyon">Mona Canyon</a>, located in the <a href="/wiki/Mona_Passage" title="Mona Passage">Mona Passage</a> between Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, is another prominent oceanic landform with steep walls measuring between 1.25 and 2.17 miles (2.01 and 3.49&#160;km) in height from bottom to top.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Climate of Puerto Rico">Climate of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png/260px-Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png" decoding="async" width="260" height="158" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png/390px-Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png/520px-Puerto_Rico_K%C3%B6ppen.png 2x" data-file-width="6600" data-file-height="4019" /></a><figcaption>K\xc3\xb6ppen climate types in Puerto Rico indicating that the island primarily has rainforest and monsoon climate types</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The climate of Puerto Rico in the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification">K\xc3\xb6ppen climate classification</a> is mostly <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">tropical rainforest</a>. Temperatures are warm to hot year round, averaging near 85&#160;\xc2\xb0F (29&#160;\xc2\xb0C) in lower elevations and 70&#160;\xc2\xb0F (21&#160;\xc2\xb0C) in the mountains. Easterly <a href="/wiki/Trade_winds" title="Trade winds">trade winds</a> pass across the island year round. Puerto Rico has a <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">rainy season</a>, which stretches from April into November, and a <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a> stretching from December to March. The mountains of the Cordillera Central create a <a href="/wiki/Rain_shadow" title="Rain shadow">rain shadow</a> and are the main cause of the variations in the temperature and rainfall that occur over very short distances. The mountains can also cause wide variation in local wind speed and direction due to their sheltering and channeling effects, adding to the climatic variation. Daily temperature changes seasonally are quite small in the lowlands and coastal areas.\n</p><p>Between the dry and wet seasons, there is a temperature change of around 6&#160;\xc2\xb0F (3.3&#160;\xc2\xb0C). This change is due mainly to the warm waters of the tropical <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, which significantly modify cooler air moving in from the north and northwest. Coastal water temperatures during the year are about 75&#160;\xc2\xb0F (24&#160;\xc2\xb0C) in February and 85&#160;\xc2\xb0F (29&#160;\xc2\xb0C) in August. The highest temperature ever recorded was 110&#160;\xc2\xb0F (43&#160;\xc2\xb0C) at <a href="/wiki/Arecibo,_Puerto_Rico" title="Arecibo, Puerto Rico">Arecibo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-:02_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while the lowest temperature ever recorded was 40&#160;\xc2\xb0F (4&#160;\xc2\xb0C) in the mountains at <a href="/wiki/Adjuntas,_Puerto_Rico" title="Adjuntas, Puerto Rico">Adjuntas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aibonito,_Puerto_Rico" title="Aibonito, Puerto Rico">Aibonito</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Corozal,_Puerto_Rico" title="Corozal, Puerto Rico">Corozal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NOAA-PR_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-PR-102"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The average yearly precipitation is 66&#160;in (1,676&#160;mm).<sup id="cite_ref-Daly2003_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daly2003-103"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Hurricanes">Hurricanes</h4></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico experiences the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_season" title="Atlantic hurricane season">Atlantic hurricane season</a>, similar to the rest of the Caribbean Sea and North Atlantic Ocean. On average, a quarter of its annual rainfall is contributed from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone" title="Tropical cyclone">tropical cyclones</a>, which are more prevalent during periods of <a href="/wiki/La_Ni%C3%B1a" class="mw-redirect" title="La Ni\xc3\xb1a">La Ni\xc3\xb1a</a> than <a href="/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o" class="mw-redirect" title="El Ni\xc3\xb1o">El Ni\xc3\xb1o</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A cyclone of tropical storm strength passes near Puerto Rico, on average, every five years. A hurricane passes in the vicinity of the island, on average, every seven years. Since 1851, the <a href="/wiki/1928_Okeechobee_Hurricane" class="mw-redirect" title="1928 Okeechobee Hurricane">Lake Okeechobee Hurricane</a> (also known as the San Felipe Segundo hurricane in Puerto Rico) of September 1928 is the only hurricane to make landfall as a Category 5 hurricane.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In the busy <a href="/wiki/2017_Atlantic_hurricane_season" title="2017 Atlantic hurricane season">2017 Atlantic hurricane season</a>, Puerto Rico avoided a direct hit by the Category 5 <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">Hurricane Irma</a> on 6 September 2017, as it passed about 60&#160;mi (97&#160;km) north of Puerto Rico, but high winds caused a loss of electrical power to some one million residents. Almost 50% of hospitals were operating with power provided by generators.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Category 4 <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Jose_(2017)" title="Hurricane Jose (2017)">Hurricane Jose</a>, as expected, veered away from Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A short time later, the devastating <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Maria" title="Hurricane Maria">Hurricane Maria</a> made landfall on Puerto Rico on Wednesday, 20 September, near the <a href="/wiki/Yabucoa" class="mw-redirect" title="Yabucoa">Yabucoa</a> municipality at 10:15&#160;UTC (6:15&#160;am local time) as a high-end Category&#160;4 hurricane with sustained winds of 155&#160;mph (249&#160;km/h), powerful rains and widespread flooding causing tremendous destruction, including the electrical grid, which would remain out for 4\xe2\x80\x936 months in many portions of the island.<sup id="cite_ref-MariaDisc18_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MariaDisc18-108"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2019, <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Dorian" title="Hurricane Dorian">Hurricane Dorian</a> became the third hurricane in three years to hit Puerto Rico. The recovering infrastructure from the 2017 hurricanes, as well as new governor <a href="/wiki/Wanda_V%C3%A1zquez_Garced" title="Wanda V\xc3\xa1zquez Garced">Wanda V\xc3\xa1zquez Garced</a>, were put to the test against a potential humanitarian crisis.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Karen_(2019)" title="Tropical Storm Karen (2019)">Tropical Storm Karen</a> also caused impacts to Puerto Rico during 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Climate_change">Climate change</h4></div>\n<div class="excerpt-block"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066933788">.mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}</style><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Climate change in Puerto Rico">Climate change in Puerto Rico</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">\n<p><a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">Climate change</a> has had large impacts on the ecosystems and landscapes of the US territory Puerto Rico. According to a 2019 report by <a href="/wiki/Germanwatch" title="Germanwatch">Germanwatch</a>, Puerto Rico is the most affected by climate change. The territory\'s energy consumption is mainly derived from imported <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" class="mw-redirect" title="Fossil fuels">fossil fuels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:12_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:12-114"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:5_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:5-115"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> \n</p><p>The Puerto Rico Climate Change Council (PRCCC) noted severe changes in seven categories: air temperature, precipitation, extreme weather events, tropical storms and hurricanes, <a href="/wiki/Ocean_acidification" title="Ocean acidification">ocean acidification</a>, sea surface temperatures, and <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">sea level rise</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:6_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:6-116"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Climate change also affects Puerto Rico\'s population, the economy, human health, and the number of people forced to migrate.\n</p>\nSurveys have shown<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness" title="Wikipedia:Vagueness"><span title="This information is too vague. (September 2023)">vague</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> climate change is a matter of concern for most Puerto Ricans.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPCCC2022106_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPCCC2022106-117"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The territory has enacted laws and policies concerning <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_mitigation" title="Climate change mitigation">climate change mitigation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_adaptation" title="Climate change adaptation">adaptation</a>, including the use of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPCCC2022104_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPCCC2022104-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Local initiatives are working toward mitigation and adaptation goals, and international aid programs support reconstruction after extreme weather events and encourage disaster planning.<sup id="cite_ref-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:2_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Climate_change_in_Puerto_Rico_:2-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></div></div>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Fauna of Puerto Rico">Fauna of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Flora of Puerto Rico">Flora of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico is home to three terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_moist_forests" title="Puerto Rican moist forests">Puerto Rican moist forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_dry_forests" title="Puerto Rican dry forests">Puerto Rican dry forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Antilles_mangroves" title="Greater Antilles mangroves">Greater Antilles mangroves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-120"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico has two biosphere reserves recognized by the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/Man_and_the_Biosphere_Programme" title="Man and the Biosphere Programme">Man and the Biosphere Programme</a>: Luquillo Biosphere Reserve represented by <a href="/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest" title="El Yunque National Forest">El Yunque National Forest</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gu%C3%A1nica_State_Forest" title="Gu\xc3\xa1nica State Forest">Gu\xc3\xa1nica Biosphere Reserve</a>.\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="In this image there is a brown coqu\xc3\xad. The species resembles a small frog." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg/220px-Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="210" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="287" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Eleutherodactylus_coqui" class="mw-redirect" title="Eleutherodactylus coqui">Common coqu\xc3\xad</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Species <a href="/wiki/Endemic_(ecology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic (ecology)">endemic</a> to the archipelago number 239 plants, 16 birds and 39 <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a>/<a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a>, recognized as of 1998. Most of these (234, 12 and 33 respectively) are found on the main island.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The most recognizable endemic species and a symbol of Puerto Rican pride is the <i><a href="/wiki/Coqu%C3%AD" title="Coqu\xc3\xad">coqu\xc3\xad</a></i>, a small frog easily identified by the sound of its call, from which it gets its name. Most <i>coqu\xc3\xad</i> species (13 of 17) live in the <a href="/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest" title="El Yunque National Forest">El Yunque National Forest</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the only <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">tropical rainforest</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forest_Service" title="United States Forest Service">U.S. Forest Service</a> system, located in the northeast of the island. It was previously known as the Caribbean National Forest. El Yunque is home to more than 240 plants, 26 of which are endemic to the island. It is also home to 50 bird species, including the critically endangered <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_amazon" title="Puerto Rican amazon">Puerto Rican amazon</a>.\n</p><p>In addition to El Yunque National Forest, the Puerto Rican moist forest ecoregion is represented by protected areas such as the <a href="/wiki/Maricao_State_Forest" title="Maricao State Forest">Maricao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Toro_Negro_State_Forest" title="Toro Negro State Forest">Toro Negro</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Puerto_Rico_state_forests" title="List of Puerto Rico state forests">state forests</a>. These areas are home to endangered endemic species such as the Puerto Rican boa (<i><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_boa" title="Puerto Rican boa">Chilabothrus inornatus</a></i>), the Puerto Rican sharp-shinned hawk (<i><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_sharp-shinned_hawk" title="Puerto Rican sharp-shinned hawk">Accipiter striatus venator</a></i>), the Puerto Rican broad-winged hawk (<i><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_broad-winged_hawk" title="Puerto Rican broad-winged hawk">Buteo platypterus brunnescens</a></i>) and the elfin woods warbler (<a href="/wiki/Elfin_woods_warbler" title="Elfin woods warbler">Setophaga angelae</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Karst" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Karst">Northern Karst</a> country of Puerto Rico is also home to one of the remaining rainforest tracts in the island, with the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Abajo_State_Forest" title="R\xc3\xado Abajo State Forest">R\xc3\xado Abajo State Forest</a> being the first focus for the reintroduction of the highly endangered Puerto Rican parrot outside of the Sierra de Luquillo.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In the southwest, the Gu\xc3\xa1nica State Forest and Biosphere Reserve contain over 600 uncommon species of plants and animals, including 48 endangered species and 16 that are endemic to Puerto Rico, and is considered a prime example of the Puerto Rican dry forest ecoregion and the best-preserved dry forest in the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other protected dry forests in Puerto Rico can be formed within the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Islands_National_Wildlife_Refuge_Complex" title="Caribbean Islands National Wildlife Refuge Complex">Caribbean Islands National Wildlife Refuge complex</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cabo_Rojo_National_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Cabo Rojo National Wildlife Refuge">Cabo Rojo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Desecheo_National_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Desecheo National Wildlife Refuge">Desecheo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culebra_National_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Culebra National Wildlife Refuge">Culebra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vieques_National_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Vieques National Wildlife Refuge">Vieques National Wildlife Refuges</a>, and in the <a href="/wiki/Caja_de_Muertos_Nature_Reserve" title="Caja de Muertos Nature Reserve">Caja de Muertos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mona_and_Monito_Islands_Nature_Reserve" title="Mona and Monito Islands Nature Reserve">Mona and Monito Islands Nature Reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ewel_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ewel-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Examples of endemic species found in this ecoregion are the higo chumbo (<i><a href="/wiki/Harrisia_portoricensis" title="Harrisia portoricensis">Harrisia portoricensis</a></i>), the Puerto Rican crested toad (<i><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_crested_toad" title="Puerto Rican crested toad">Peltophryne lemur</a></i>), and the Mona ground iguana (<i><a href="/wiki/Mona_ground_iguana" title="Mona ground iguana">Cyclura stejnegeri</a></i>), the largest land animal native to Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-alberts_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alberts-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has three of the seven year-long <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bioluminescent_bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bioluminescent bay (page does not exist)">bioluminescent bays</a> in the Caribbean: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Las_Cabezas_de_San_Juan_(Puerto_Rico)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Las Cabezas de San Juan (Puerto Rico) (page does not exist)">Laguna Grande</a> in <a href="/wiki/Fajardo,_Puerto_Rico" title="Fajardo, Puerto Rico">Fajardo</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Parguera_Nature_Reserve" title="La Parguera Nature Reserve">La Parguera</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lajas,_Puerto_Rico" title="Lajas, Puerto Rico">Lajas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Mosquito" title="Puerto Mosquito">Puerto Mosquito</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vieques,_Puerto_Rico" title="Vieques, Puerto Rico">Vieques</a>. These are unique bodies of water surrounded by <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">mangroves</a> that are inhabited by the <a href="/wiki/Dinoflagellate" title="Dinoflagellate">dinoflagellate</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Pyrodinium_bahamense" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyrodinium bahamense">Pyrodinium bahamense</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-128"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, tourism, pollution, and hurricanes have highly threatened these unique ecosystems.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</h2></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Government of Puerto Rico">Government of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Politics of Puerto Rico">Politics of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico has a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republican form of government</a> based on the <a href="/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States" title="Republicanism in the United States">American model</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> subject to the jurisdiction and sovereignty of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-131"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ussd_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ussd-132"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> All governmental powers are delegated by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a>, with the head of state being the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a>. As an <a href="/wiki/Unincorporated_territories_of_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Unincorporated territories of the United States">unincorporated territory</a>, Puerto Rico lacks full protection under the U.S. Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-U.S._Department_of_State_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-U.S._Department_of_State-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The government of Puerto Rico is composed of three branches. The executive is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Governor of Puerto Rico">governor</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Pierluisi_Urrutia" class="mw-redirect" title="Pedro Pierluisi Urrutia">Pedro Pierluisi Urrutia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico">legislative branch</a> consists of the <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico">Legislative Assembly</a>, made up of a <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Senate of Puerto Rico">Senate</a> as its upper chamber and a <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_Puerto_Rico" title="House of Representatives of Puerto Rico">House of Representatives</a> as its lower chamber; the Senate is headed by a <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Senate_of_Puerto_Rico" title="President of the Senate of Puerto Rico">president</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Dalmau" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 Luis Dalmau">Jos\xc3\xa9 Luis Dalmau</a>, while the House is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_House_of_Representatives_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Speaker of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico">speaker of the House</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Tatito_Hern%C3%A1ndez" title="Tatito Hern\xc3\xa1ndez">Tatito Hern\xc3\xa1ndez</a>. The governor and legislators are elected by popular vote every four years, with <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_general_election,_2020" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican general election, 2020">the last election held in November 2020</a>.
