The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Judiciary of Puerto Rico">judicial branch</a> is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico">chief justice of the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Maite_Oronoz_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Maite Oronoz Rodr\xc3\xadguez">Maite Oronoz Rodr\xc3\xadguez</a>. Members of the judiciary are appointed by the governor with the <a href="/wiki/Advice_and_consent" title="Advice and consent">advice and consent</a> of the Senate.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico is represented in the U.S. Congress by a nonvoting delegate to the House of Representatives, the <a href="/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico">resident commissioner</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Jenniffer_Gonz%C3%A1lez" class="mw-redirect" title="Jenniffer Gonz\xc3\xa1lez">Jenniffer Gonz\xc3\xa1lez</a>. Current congressional rules have removed the commissioner\'s power to vote in the <a href="/wiki/Committee_of_the_Whole_(United_States_House_of_Representatives)" title="Committee of the Whole (United States House of Representatives)">Committee of the Whole</a>, but the commissioner can vote in committee.<sup id="cite_ref-rhg_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rhg-134"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rican elections are governed by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Election_Commission" title="Federal Election Commission">Federal Election Commission</a> and the <a href="/wiki/State_Elections_Commission_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="State Elections Commission of Puerto Rico">State Elections Commission of Puerto Rico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Residents of Puerto Rico, including other U.S. citizens, cannot vote in U.S. presidential elections, but can vote in <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_primary" title="United States presidential primary">primaries</a>. Puerto Ricans who become residents of a <a href="/wiki/U.S._state" title="U.S. state">U.S. state</a> or <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> can vote in presidential elections.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_senatorial_districts" title="Puerto Rico senatorial districts">eight senatorial districts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_representative_districts" title="Puerto Rico representative districts">40 representative districts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Municipalities of Puerto Rico">78 municipalities</a>; there are no first-order administrative divisions as defined by the U.S. government. Municipalities are subdivided into wards or <a href="/wiki/Barrio" title="Barrio">barrios</a>, and those into sectors. Each municipality has a <a href="/wiki/Mayors_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayors of Puerto Rico">mayor</a> and a municipal legislature elected for a four-year term. The municipality of <a href="/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico" title="San Juan, Puerto Rico">San Juan</a> is the oldest, founded in 1521;<sup id="cite_ref-linktopr.com_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-linktopr.com-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the next earliest settlements are <a href="/wiki/San_Germ%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="San Germ\xc3\xa1n">San Germ\xc3\xa1n</a> in 1570, <a href="/wiki/Coamo" class="mw-redirect" title="Coamo">Coamo</a> in 1579, <a href="/wiki/Arecibo" class="mw-redirect" title="Arecibo">Arecibo</a> in 1614, <a href="/wiki/Aguada,_Puerto_Rico" title="Aguada, Puerto Rico">Aguada</a> in 1692 and <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce</a> in 1692. Increased settlement in the 18th century saw 30 more communities established, following 34 in the 19th century. Six were founded in the 20th century, the most recent being <a href="/wiki/Florida,_Puerto_Rico" title="Florida, Puerto Rico">Florida</a> in 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-fundacion_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fundacion-138"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Political_parties_and_elections">Political parties and elections</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Political party strength in Puerto Rico">Political party strength in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png/220px-Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png/330px-Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png/440px-Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png 2x" data-file-width="2445" data-file-height="2445" /></a><figcaption>The difference between the incumbent party, the PPD, and its opponent, the PNP, was a mere 0.6% in the last election. This difference is common as the political landscape experiences political cycles between both parties, with the PPD ruling all branches of government for 36 of the past 64 years. The PNP, on the other hand, has ruled both the executive and legislative branch concurrently for 16 years. The other 12 years experienced a <a href="/wiki/Divided_government_in_the_United_States" title="Divided government in the United States">divided government</a>.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Since 1952, Puerto Rico has had three main political parties: the <a href="/wiki/Popular_Democratic_Party_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Popular Democratic Party (Puerto Rico)">Popular Democratic Party</a> (PPD in Spanish), the <a href="/wiki/New_Progressive_Party_(Puerto_Rico)" title="New Progressive Party (Puerto Rico)">New Progressive Party</a> (PNP in Spanish) and the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Independence_Party" title="Puerto Rican Independence Party">Puerto Rican Independence Party</a> (PIP). The three parties stand for different political status. The PPD, for example, seeks <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_movement_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Status quo movement in Puerto Rico">to maintain the island\'s status with the U.S. as a commonwealth</a>, while the PNP seeks <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_statehood_movement" title="Puerto Rico statehood movement">to make Puerto Rico a U.S. state</a>. Meanwhile, the PIP seeks <a href="/wiki/Independence_movement_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Independence movement in Puerto Rico">to make Puerto Rico a sovereign nation</a> free from U.S. authority. In terms of party strength, the PPD and PNP usually hold about 47% of the vote each while the PIP holds about 5%.\n</p><p>After 2007, other parties emerged on the island. The first, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans_for_Puerto_Rico_Party" title="Puerto Ricans for Puerto Rico Party">Puerto Ricans for Puerto Rico Party</a> was registered that same year. The party claims that it seeks to address the islands\' problems from a status-neutral platform. But it ceased to remain as a registered party when it failed to obtain the required number of votes in the 2008 general election. Four years later, the 2012 election saw the emergence of the <i><a href="/wiki/Movimiento_Uni%C3%B3n_Soberanista" title="Movimiento Uni\xc3\xb3n Soberanista">Movimiento Uni\xc3\xb3n Soberanista</a></i> (English: Sovereign Union Movement) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Partido_del_Pueblo_Trabajador" class="mw-redirect" title="Partido del Pueblo Trabajador">Partido del Pueblo Trabajador</a></i> (English: Working People\'s Party) but none obtained more than 1% of the vote.\n</p><p>Other non-registered parties include the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Nationalist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican Nationalist Party">Puerto Rican Nationalist Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Workers_Movement_(Puerto_Rico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Socialist Workers Movement (Puerto Rico)">Socialist Workers Movement</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Hostosian_National_Independence_Movement" title="Hostosian National Independence Movement">Hostosian National Independence Movement</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Political_status">Political status</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Political status of Puerto Rico">Political status of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proposed_political_status_for_Puerto_Rico" title="Proposed political status for Puerto Rico">Proposed political status for Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The nature of Puerto Rico\'s political relationship with the U.S. is the subject of <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico#Controversies" title="Political status of Puerto Rico">ongoing debate</a> in Puerto Rico, the U.S. Congress, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sdc_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sdc-139"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Specifically, the basic question is whether Puerto Rico should remain an unincorporated territory of the U.S., become a U.S. state, or become an independent country.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:PR_Capitol,_south_side.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG/220px-PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG/330px-PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG/440px-PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2124" data-file-height="1672" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Capitol_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Capitol of Puerto Rico">Capitol of Puerto Rico</a>, home of the Legislative Assembly in Puerto Rico</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Constitutionally, Puerto Rico is subject to the <a href="/wiki/Plenary_powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Plenary powers">plenary powers</a> of the U.S. Congress under the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_clause" class="mw-redirect" title="Territorial clause">territorial clause</a> of <a href="/wiki/Article_Four_of_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Article Four of the United States Constitution">Article IV of the U.S. Constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/U.S._federal_law" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. federal law">Laws enacted at the federal level in the U.S.</a> apply to Puerto Rico as well, regardless of its political status. Their residents <a href="/wiki/Federal_voting_rights_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Federal voting rights in Puerto Rico">do not have voting representation in the U.S. Congress</a>. Puerto Rico lacks "the full sovereignty of an independent nation", for example, the power to manage its "external relations with other nations", which is held by the U.S. federal government. The U.S. Supreme Court has indicated that once the U.S. Constitution has been extended to an area (by Congress or the courts), its coverage is irrevocable. To hold that the political branches may switch the Constitution on or off at will would lead to a regime in which they, not this Court, say "what the law is".<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Ricans "were collectively made U.S. citizens" in 1917 as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Jones%E2%80%93Shafroth_Act" title="Jones\xe2\x80\x93Shafroth Act">Jones\xe2\x80\x93Shafroth Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> U.S. citizens residing in Puerto Rico cannot vote in U.S. presidential elections, though both major parties, Republican and Democratic, hold primary elections in Puerto Rico to choose delegates to vote on the parties\' presidential candidates. Since Puerto Rico is an unincorporated territory and not a U.S. state, the U.S. Constitution does not fully <a href="/wiki/Enfranchise" class="mw-redirect" title="Enfranchise">enfranchise</a> U.S. citizens residing in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-U.S._Department_of_State_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-U.S._Department_of_State-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Constitutional_Topic:_Citizenship_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitutional_Topic:_Citizenship-144"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Only <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_right" class="mw-redirect" title="Fundamental right">fundamental rights</a> under the American federal constitution and adjudications are applied to Puerto Ricans. Various other U.S. Supreme Court decisions have held which rights apply in Puerto Rico and which ones do not. Puerto Ricans have a long history of service in the U.S. Armed Forces and, since 1917, they have been included in the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_draft" class="mw-redirect" title="Compulsory draft">compulsory draft</a> when it has been in effect.\n</p><p>Though the Commonwealth government has its own tax laws, residents of Puerto Rico, contrary to a popular misconception, do pay U.S. federal taxes: customs taxes (which are subsequently returned to the Puerto Rico Treasury), import/export taxes, federal commodity taxes, social security taxes, etc. Residents pay federal <a href="/wiki/Payroll_tax" title="Payroll tax">payroll taxes</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">Social Security</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">Medicare</a>, as well as Commonwealth of Puerto Rico income taxes. All federal employees, those who do business with the federal government, Puerto Rico-based corporations that intend to send funds to the U.S., and some others, such as Puerto Rican residents that are members of the U.S. military, and Puerto Rico residents who earned income from sources outside Puerto Rico also pay federal income taxes. In addition, because the cutoff point for income taxation is lower than that of the U.S. IRS code, and because the per-capita income in Puerto Rico is much lower than the average per-capita income on the mainland, more Puerto Rico residents pay income taxes to the local taxation authority than if the IRS code were applied to the island. This occurs because "the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico government has a wider set of responsibilities than do U.S. State and local governments."<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-reuters2009-09-24_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters2009-09-24-147"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jct_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jct-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, Puerto Rico paid <span class="nowrap">$3.742 billion</span> into the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Treasury" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Treasury">U.S. Treasury</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Residents of Puerto Rico pay into Social Security, and are thus eligible for Social Security benefits upon retirement. They are excluded from the <a href="/wiki/Supplemental_Security_Income" title="Supplemental Security Income">Supplemental Security Income</a>, and the island receives a smaller fraction of the <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">Medicaid</a> funding it would receive if it were a U.S. state.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Also, Medicare providers receive less-than-full state-like reimbursements for services rendered to beneficiaries in Puerto Rico, even though the latter paid fully into the system.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico\'s authority to enact a criminal code derives from Congress and not from local sovereignty as with the states. Thus, individuals committing a crime can only be tried in federal or territorial court, otherwise it would constitute double jeopardy and is constitutionally impermissible.<sup id="cite_ref-Mart\xc3\xadnez_Torres_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mart\xc3\xadnez_Torres-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1992, President <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> issued a memorandum to heads of executive departments and agencies establishing the current administrative relationship between the federal government and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. This memorandum directs all federal departments, agencies, and officials to treat Puerto Rico administratively as if it were a state, insofar as doing so would not disrupt federal programs or operations.\n</p><p>Many federal executive branch agencies have significant presence in Puerto Rico, just as in any state, including the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency" title="Federal Emergency Management Agency">Federal Emergency Management Agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transportation_Security_Administration" title="Transportation Security Administration">Transportation Security Administration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_Administration" title="Social Security Administration">Social Security Administration</a>, and others. While Puerto Rico has its own <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Judiciary of Puerto Rico">Commonwealth judicial system</a> similar to that of a U.S. state, there is also a U.S. federal district court in Puerto Rico, and Puerto Ricans have served as judges in that Court and in other federal courts on the U.S. mainland regardless of their residency status at the time of their appointment. <a href="/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor" title="Sonia Sotomayor">Sonia Sotomayor</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Nuyorican" title="Nuyorican">New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent</a>, serves as an <a href="/wiki/Associate_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="Associate Justice">associate justice</a> of the U.S. Supreme Court. Puerto Ricans have also been frequently appointed to high-level federal positions, including serving as <a href="/wiki/U.S._ambassadors" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. ambassadors">U.S. ambassadors</a> to other nations.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</h3></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg/220px-USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="68" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg/330px-USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg/440px-USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1058" data-file-height="325" /></a><figcaption>A map of Puerto Rico showing its 78 municipalities; the islands of Vieques and Culebra have their own municipal governments.</figcaption></figure>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Municipalities of Puerto Rico">Municipalities of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Unlike the vast majority of U.S. states, Puerto Rico has no first-order administrative divisions akin to <a href="/wiki/County_(United_States)" title="County (United States)">counties</a>, but has 78 <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipalities</a> or <a href="/wiki/Municipio" title="Municipio"><i>municipios</i></a> as the secondary unit of administration; for <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">U.S. Census</a> purposes, the municipalities are considered <a href="/wiki/County_(United_States)#County_equivalents" title="County (United States)">county equivalents</a>. Municipalities are subdivided into <i><a href="/wiki/Barrio" title="Barrio">barrios</a></i>, and those into sectors. Each municipality has a <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">mayor</a> and a municipal legislature elected for four-year terms, per the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Municipalities_Act_of_1991" title="Autonomous Municipalities Act of 1991">Autonomous Municipalities Act of 1991</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_and_intergovernmental_relations">Foreign and intergovernmental relations</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_and_intergovernmental_relations_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Foreign and intergovernmental relations of Puerto Rico">Foreign and intergovernmental relations of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico is subject to the <a href="/wiki/Commerce_Clause" title="Commerce Clause">Commerce</a> and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_Clause" class="mw-redirect" title="Territorial Clause">Territorial Clause</a> of the U.S. Constitution and is thus restricted on how it can engage with other nations, sharing the opportunities and limitations that state governments have albeit not being one. As is the case with state governments, it has established several trade agreements with other nations, particularly with Latin American countries such as Colombia and Panam\xc3\xa1.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>It has also established trade promotion offices in many foreign countries, all Spanish-speaking, and within the U.S. itself, which now include Spain, the Dominican Republic, <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, New York City and Florida, and has included in the past offices in <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>. Such agreements require permission from the U.S. Department of State; most are simply allowed by existing laws or trade treaties between the U.S. and other nations which supersede trade agreements pursued by Puerto Rico and different U.S. states. Puerto Rico hosts <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consulates</a> from 41 countries, mainly from the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> and Europe, with most located in San Juan.<sup id="cite_ref-linktopr.com_137-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-linktopr.com-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>At the local level, Puerto Rico established by law that the international relations which states and territories are allowed to engage must be handled by the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_State_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of State of Puerto Rico">Department of State of Puerto Rico</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Executive_departments_of_the_government_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive departments of the government of Puerto Rico">executive department</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Secretary of State of Puerto Rico">secretary of state of Puerto Rico</a>, who also serves as the unincorporated territory\'s lieutenant governor. It is also charged to liaise with general <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consuls</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honorary_consul" class="mw-redirect" title="Honorary consul">honorary consuls</a> based in Puerto Rico. The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Federal_Affairs_Administration" title="Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration">Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration</a>, along with the <a href="/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico">Office of the Resident Commissioner</a>, manages all its intergovernmental affairs before entities of or in the U.S. (including the federal government of the U.S., local and state governments of the U.S., and public or private entities in the U.S.).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>Both entities frequently assist the Department of State of Puerto Rico in engaging with Washington, D.C.-based ambassadors and federal agencies that handle Puerto Rico\'s foreign affairs, such as the U.S. Department of State, the <a href="/wiki/Agency_for_International_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Agency for International Development">Agency for International Development</a>, and others. The current secretary of state is <a href="/wiki/Larry_Seilhamer_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Larry Seilhamer Rodr\xc3\xadguez">Larry Seilhamer Rodr\xc3\xadguez</a> from the New Progressive Party, while the current <a href="/wiki/List_of_Directors_of_the_Puerto_Rico_Federal_Affairs_Administration" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Directors of the Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration">director of the Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration</a> is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennifer_M._Stopiran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennifer M. Stopiran (page does not exist)">Jennifer M. Stopiran</a> also from the NPP and a member of the Republican Party of the U.S.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2024)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico">resident commissioner of Puerto Rico</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Delegate_(United_States_Congress)" class="mw-redirect" title="Delegate (United States Congress)">delegate</a> elected by Puerto Ricans to represent them before the federal government, including the U.S. Congress, sits in the U.S. House of Representatives, serves and votes on congressional committees, and functions in every respect as a legislator except being denied a vote on the final disposition of legislation on the House floor. The current resident commissioner is <a href="/wiki/Jenniffer_Gonz%C3%A1lez" class="mw-redirect" title="Jenniffer Gonz\xc3\xa1lez">Jenniffer Gonz\xc3\xa1lez-Col\xc3\xb3n</a>, a Republican, elected in 2016. She received more votes than any other official elected in Puerto Rico that year.<sup id="cite_ref-wines19_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wines19-158"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Many Puerto Ricans have served as U.S. ambassadors to different nations and international organizations, such as the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a>, mostly but not exclusively in Latin America. For example, Maricarmen Aponte, a Puerto Rican and now an acting assistant secretary of state, previously served as <a href="/wiki/List_of_ambassadors_of_the_United_States_to_El_Salvador" title="List of ambassadors of the United States to El Salvador">U.S. ambassador to El Salvador</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military">Military</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Military_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Military of Puerto Rico">Military of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG/440px-Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG" decoding="async" width="440" height="94" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG/660px-Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG/880px-Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1312" data-file-height="280" /></a><figcaption>U.S. military installations and other federal lands in Puerto Rico (including the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Virgin_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Virgin Islands">U.S. Virgin Islands</a>) throughout the 20th century</figcaption></figure>\n<p>As it is an unincorporated U.S. territory, the defense of Puerto Rico is provided by the U.S. as part of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">Treaty of Paris</a> with the president of the U.S. as its <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a>. Puerto Rico has its own <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_National_Guard" title="Puerto Rico National Guard">National Guard</a>, and its own <a href="/wiki/State_defense_force" title="State defense force">state defense force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_State_Guard" title="Puerto Rico State Guard">Puerto Rico State Guard</a>, which by local law is under the authority of the Puerto Rico National Guard.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of both local forces is the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Governor of Puerto Rico">governor of Puerto Rico</a> who delegates his authority to the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Adjutant_General" title="Puerto Rico Adjutant General">Puerto Rico adjutant general</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Major_General" class="mw-redirect" title="Major General">Major General</a> <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_J._Reyes" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 J. Reyes">Jos\xc3\xa9 J. Reyes</a>. The Adjutant General, in turn, delegates the authority over the State Guard to another officer but retains the authority over the Puerto Rico National Guard as a whole.\nU.S. military installations in Puerto Rico were part of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Atlantic_Command" title="United States Atlantic Command">U.S. Atlantic Command</a> (LANTCOM after 1993 USACOM), which had authority over all U.S. military operations that took place throughout the Atlantic. Puerto Rico had been seen as crucial in supporting LANTCOM\'s mission until 1999, when U.S. Atlantic Command was renamed and given a new mission as <a href="/wiki/U.S._Joint_Forces_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Joint Forces Command">U.S. Joint Forces Command</a>. Puerto Rico is currently under the responsibility of <a href="/wiki/U.S._Northern_Command" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Northern Command">U.S. Northern Command</a>.\n</p><p>Both the Naval Forces Caribbean (NFC) and the Fleet Air Caribbean (FAIR) were formerly based at the Roosevelt Roads Naval Station. The NFC had authority over all U.S. Naval activity in the waters of the Caribbean while FAIR had authority over all U.S. military flights and air operations over the Caribbean. With the closing of the Roosevelt Roads and Vieques Island training facilities, the U.S. Navy has basically exited from Puerto Rico, except for the ships that steam by, and the only significant military presence in the island is the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Army" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Army">U.S. Army</a> at <a href="/wiki/Fort_Buchanan,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Buchanan, Puerto Rico">Ft Buchanan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican Army">Puerto Rican Army</a> and Air National Guards, and the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Coast Guard">U.S. Coast Guard</a>. Protests over the noise of bombing practice forced the closure of the naval base. This resulted in a loss of 6,000 jobs and an annual decrease in local income of $300&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>A branch of the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Army_National_Guard" title="Army National Guard">Army National Guard</a> is stationed in Puerto Rico \xe2\x80\x93 known as the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Army_National_Guard" title="Puerto Rico Army National Guard">Puerto Rico Army National Guard</a> \xe2\x80\x93 which performs missions equivalent to those of the Army National Guards of different U.S. states, including ground defense, disaster relief, and control of civil unrest. The local National Guard also incorporates a branch of the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Air_National_Guard" title="Air National Guard">Air National Guard</a> \xe2\x80\x93 known as the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Air_National_Guard" title="Puerto Rico Air National Guard">Puerto Rico Air National Guard</a> \xe2\x80\x93 which performs missions equivalent to those of the Air National Guards of each one of the U.S. states.\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:USS_Maryland_(SSBN-738)_1997.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg/220px-USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg/330px-USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg/440px-USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1000" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Ohio-class_submarine" title="Ohio-class submarine"><i>Ohio</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile submarine</a> USS <i>Maryland</i>, <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Roads_Naval_Station" title="Roosevelt Roads Naval Station">Roosevelt Roads Naval Station</a>, 1997</figcaption></figure>\n<p>At different times in the 20th century, the U.S. had about 25 military or naval installations in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-WQS_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WQS-161"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The largest of these installations were the former <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Roads_Naval_Station" title="Roosevelt Roads Naval Station">Roosevelt Roads Naval Station</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ceiba,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ceiba, Puerto Rico">Ceiba</a>, the Atlantic Fleet Weapons Training Facility (AFWTF) on <a href="/wiki/Vieques" class="mw-redirect" title="Vieques">Vieques</a>, the National Guard training facility at <a href="/wiki/Camp_Santiago" class="mw-redirect" title="Camp Santiago">Camp Santiago</a> in <a href="/wiki/Salinas,_Puerto_Rico" title="Salinas, Puerto Rico">Salinas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fort_Allen,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Allen, Puerto Rico">Fort Allen</a> in <a href="/wiki/Juana_Diaz" class="mw-redirect" title="Juana Diaz">Juana Diaz</a>, the Army\'s <a href="/wiki/Fort_Buchanan,_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Buchanan, Puerto Rico">Fort Buchanan</a> in San Juan, the former U.S. Air Force\'s Ramey Air Force Base in Aguadilla, and the Puerto Rico Air National Guard\'s <a href="/wiki/Mu%C3%B1iz_Air_National_Guard_Base" title="Mu\xc3\xb1iz Air National Guard Base">Mu\xc3\xb1iz Air National Guard Base</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico" title="San Juan, Puerto Rico">San Juan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CD_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CD-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The former U.S. Navy facilities at Roosevelt Roads, Vieques, and Sabana Seca have been deactivated and partially turned over to the local government. Other than <a href="/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Coast Guard">U.S. Coast Guard</a> and Puerto Rico National Guard facilities, there are only two remaining military installations in Puerto Rico: the U.S. Army\'s small Ft. Buchanan (supporting local veterans and reserve units) and the PRANG (Puerto Rico Air National Guard) Mu\xc3\xb1iz Air Base (the C-130 Fleet). In recent years, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Congress">U.S. Congress</a> has considered their deactivations, but these have been opposed by diverse public and private entities in Puerto Rico \xe2\x80\x93 such as retired military who rely on Ft. Buchanan for the services available there.\n</p><p>Puerto Ricans have participated in many U.S. military conflicts, including the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, when volunteers from Puerto Rico, <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> fought the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">British</a> in 1779 under the command of General <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_de_G%C3%A1lvez" title="Bernardo de G\xc3\xa1lvez">Bernardo de G\xc3\xa1lvez</a> (1746\xe2\x80\x931786).<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They continue to be disproportionately represented in present-day conflicts in <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The most notable example is the <a href="/wiki/65th_Infantry_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="65th Infantry Regiment">65th Infantry Regiment</a> of the U.S. Army, nicknamed <i>The Borinqueneers,</i> from the original Ta\xc3\xadno name of the island (Borinquen). The all-<a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican people">Puerto Rican</a> regiment participated in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" class="mw-redirect" title="War on Terror">War on Terror</a>; in 2014, it was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Gold_Medal" title="Congressional Gold Medal">Congressional Gold Medal</a> for its heroism during the Korean War.\n</p><p>A significant number of Puerto Ricans serve in the U.S. Armed Forces, largely as <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="National Guard of the United States">National Guard</a> members and civilian employees. The size of the overall military-related community is estimated to be 100,000, including retired personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-CD_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CD-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Fort Buchanan has about 4,000 military and civilian personnel. In addition, approximately 17,000 people are members of the Puerto Rico Army and Air National Guards, or the U.S. Reserve forces.<sup id="cite_ref-OSD_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OSD-165"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Law">Law</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Constitution of Puerto Rico">Constitution of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Law of Puerto Rico">Law of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The insular legal system is a blend of <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common law</a> systems.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico is the only current U.S. jurisdiction whose legal system operates primarily in a language other than American English: namely, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>. Because the <a href="/wiki/U.S._federal_government" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. federal government">U.S. federal government</a> operates primarily in English, all Puerto Rican attorneys must be bilingual in order to litigate in English in <a href="/wiki/U.S._federal_courts" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. federal courts">U.S. federal courts</a>, and litigate federal preemption issues in Puerto Rican courts.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (March 2021)">original research?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Title_48_of_the_United_States_Code" title="Title 48 of the United States Code">Title 48 of the United States Code</a> outlines the role of the U.S. Code to U.S. territories and insular areas such as Puerto Rico. After the U.S. government assumed control of Puerto Rico in 1901, it initiated legal reforms resulting in the adoption of codes of criminal law, criminal procedure, and civil procedure modeled after those then in effect in <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>. Although Puerto Rico has since followed the federal example of transferring criminal and civil procedure from <a href="/wiki/Statutory_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Statutory law">statutory law</a> to rules promulgated by the judiciary, several portions of its criminal law still reflect the influence of the <a href="/wiki/California_Penal_Code" title="California Penal Code">California Penal Code</a>.\n</p><p>The judicial branch is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="Chief Justice">chief justice</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Supreme_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico Supreme Court">Puerto Rico Supreme Court</a>, which is the only appellate court required by the Constitution. All other courts are created by the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico">Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There is also a <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_District_of_Puerto_Rico" title="United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico">Federal District Court for Puerto Rico</a>, and someone accused of a criminal act at the federal level may not be accused for the same act in a Commonwealth court, and vice versa, since Puerto Rico as an unincorporated territory lacks sovereignty separate from Congress as a state does.<sup id="cite_ref-Mart\xc3\xadnez_Torres_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mart\xc3\xadnez_Torres-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Such a parallel accusation would constitute <a href="/wiki/Double_jeopardy" title="Double jeopardy">double jeopardy</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Crime">Crime</h4></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Crime in Puerto Rico">Crime in Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illegal_drugs_in_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Illegal drugs in Puerto Rico">Illegal drugs in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The homicide rate of 19.2 per 100,000 inhabitants was significantly higher than any U.S. state in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most homicide victims are gang members and drug traffickers with about 80% of homicides in Puerto Rico being drug related.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1992, the FBI made armed <a href="/wiki/Carjacking" title="Carjacking">carjacking</a> a federal crime and rates decreased per statistics,<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but as of 2019, the problem continued in municipalities like Guaynabo and others.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From 1 January 2019 to 14 March 2019, thirty carjackings had occurred on the island.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Economy of Puerto Rico">Economy of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-debt_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico government-debt crisis">Puerto Rico government-debt crisis</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg/300px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="212" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg/450px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg/600px-GDP_per_capita_development_in_Puerto_Rico.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="850" data-file-height="600" /></a><figcaption>Real <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> per capita development of Puerto Rico</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rico is classified as a <a href="/wiki/High_income_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="High income economy">high income economy</a> by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Advanced_economies_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Advanced_economies-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is considered the most competitive economy in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> by the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> and ranks highly on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">gross national income</a> per capita in Puerto Rico in 2020 was $21,740.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico\'s economy is mainly driven by <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Manufacturing in Puerto Rico">manufacturing</a> (primarily pharmaceuticals, textiles, petrochemicals and electronics) followed by services (primarily finance, insurance, <a href="/wiki/Real_estate_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Real estate in Puerto Rico">real estate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Tourism in Puerto Rico">tourism</a>); agriculture represents less than 1% of GNP.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>o<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>p<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In recent years, it has also become a popular destination for MICE (<a href="/wiki/Meetings,_incentives,_conferencing,_exhibitions" class="mw-redirect" title="Meetings, incentives, conferencing, exhibitions">meetings, incentives, conferencing, exhibitions</a>), with a modern <a href="/wiki/Isla_Verde,_Puerto_Rico" title="Isla Verde, Puerto Rico">convention center district</a> overlooking the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_San_Juan" title="Port of San Juan">Port of San Juan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Responsibility for San Juan <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">port</a> inspections lies with <a href="/wiki/Plant_Protection_and_Quarantine" title="Plant Protection and Quarantine">PPQ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Interceptions_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interceptions-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> So high is the volume of <a href="/wiki/Cargo" title="Cargo">cargo</a> traffic that between 1984\xe2\x80\x932000 the San Juan PPQ station recorded 7.74% of all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pest_surveillance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pest surveillance (page does not exist)">interceptions</a>, #4 in the country, #2 for insects and #3 for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agricultural_pathogen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agricultural pathogen (page does not exist)">pathogens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Interceptions_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interceptions-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most species are originally from <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> or elsewhere in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> due to PR\'s position as an intermediary on the way to the mainland.<sup id="cite_ref-Interceptions_183-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interceptions-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This is one of the worst locations for <a href="/wiki/Cut_flowers" title="Cut flowers">cut flowers</a> and other plant parts \xe2\x80\x93 both in terms of number of problems and diversity of species \xe2\x80\x93 for insects in plant parts in <a href="/wiki/Baggage" title="Baggage">baggage</a>, and for pathogens in plant parts in baggage and cargo.<sup id="cite_ref-Interceptions_183-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interceptions-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Pathogen interceptions were dramatically (17%) higher 1999\xe2\x80\x932000 than in 1985\xe2\x80\x931986.<sup id="cite_ref-Interceptions_183-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interceptions-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Geography of Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico\'s geography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Political status of Puerto Rico">political status</a> are both determining factors for its economic prosperity, primarily due to its relatively small size; <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource_economics" title="Natural resource economics">lack of natural resources</a> and subsequent dependence on <a href="/wiki/Import" title="Import">imports</a>; and vulnerability to U.S. <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> and trading restrictions, particularly concerning <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Transportation in Puerto Rico">its shipping industry</a>.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico experienced a recession from 2006 to 2011, interrupted by four quarters of economic growth, and entered into recession again in 2013, following growing fiscal imbalance and the expiration of the IRS Section 936 corporate incentives that the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Code" title="Internal Revenue Code">U.S. Internal Revenue Code</a> had applied to Puerto Rico. This IRS section was critical to the economy, as it established <a href="/wiki/Tax_exemption" title="Tax exemption">tax exemptions</a> for U.S. corporations that settled in Puerto Rico and allowed their insular subsidiaries to send their earnings to the parent corporation at any time, without paying federal tax on corporate income. Puerto Rico has been able to maintain a relatively low inflation in the past decade while maintaining a <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> per capita higher than 80% of the rest of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png/350px-Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="350" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png/525px-Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png/700px-Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png 2x" data-file-width="1560" data-file-height="1560" /></a><figcaption>Puerto Rico\'s <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> by <a href="/wiki/Economic_sector" title="Economic sector">economic sector</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Academically, most of Puerto Rico\'s economic woes stem from federal regulations that expired, have been repealed, or no longer apply to Puerto Rico; its inability to become self-sufficient and self-sustainable throughout history;<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>q<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> its highly politicized public policy which tends to change <a href="/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Political party strength in Puerto Rico">whenever a political party gains power</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>r<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Government of Puerto Rico">its highly inefficient local government</a><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>s<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>t<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which has accrued a <a href="/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Public debt of Puerto Rico">public debt</a> equal to 68% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> throughout time.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>u<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>v<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico currently has a public debt of $72.204&#160;billion (equivalent to 103% of GNP), and a government deficit of $2.5&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wef-gcr-2013_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wef-gcr-2013-197"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>By American standards, Puerto Rico is underdeveloped: It is poorer than Mississippi, the poorest state of the U.S., with 41% of its population below the <a href="/wiki/Poverty_threshold" title="Poverty threshold">poverty line</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>w<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, it has the highest <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> per capita in Latin America. Puerto Rico\'s main trading partners are the United States, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, with most products coming from <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, mainly <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Puerto Rico\'s dependency on oil for <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Transportation in Puerto Rico">transportation</a> and electricity generation, as well as its dependency on food imports and raw materials, makes Puerto Rico volatile and highly reactive to changes in <a href="/wiki/Global_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Global economy">the world economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tourism">Tourism</h3></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Beach_in_Coto,_Isabela,_Puerto_Rico.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg/220px-Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg/330px-Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg/440px-Beach_in_Coto%2C_Isabela%2C_Puerto_Rico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="753" /></a><figcaption>Beach in Coto, <a href="/wiki/Isabela,_Puerto_Rico" title="Isabela, Puerto Rico">Isabela</a></figcaption></figure>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Tourism in Puerto Rico">Tourism in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Tourism in Puerto Rico">Tourism in Puerto Rico</a> is also an important part of the economy. In 2017, <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Maria" title="Hurricane Maria">Hurricane Maria</a> caused severe damage to the island and its infrastructure, disrupting tourism for many months. The damage was estimated at $100&#160;billion. An April 2019 report indicated that by that time, only a few hotels were still closed, that life for tourists in and around the capital had, for the most part, returned to normal.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By October 2019, nearly all of the popular amenities for tourists, in the major destinations such as San Juan, Ponce and Arecibo, were in operation on the island and tourism was rebounding. This was important for the economy, since tourism provides up to 10% of Puerto Rico\'s GDP, according to Discover Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>A tourism campaign was launched by Discover Puerto Rico in 2018 intended to highlight the island\'s culture and history, branding it distinct, and different from other Caribbean destinations. In 2019, Discover Puerto Rico planned to continue that campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Fiscal_debt">Fiscal debt</h3></div>\n<p>In early 2017, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_government-debt_crisis" title="Puerto Rican government-debt crisis">Puerto Rican government-debt crisis</a> posed serious problems for the government which was saddled with outstanding bond debt that had climbed to $70&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The debt had been increasing during a decade-long recession.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The Commonwealth had been defaulting on many debts, including bonds, since 2015. With debt payments due, the governor was facing the risk of a government shutdown and failure to fund the managed health care system.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Watson_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> "Without action before April, Puerto Rico\'s ability to execute contracts for Fiscal Year 2018 with its managed care organizations will be threatened, thereby putting at risk beginning July 1, 2017 the health care of up to 900,000 poor U.S. citizens living in Puerto Rico", according to a letter sent to Congress by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. They also said that "Congress must enact measures recommended by both Republicans and Democrats that fix Puerto Rico\'s inequitable health care financing structure and promote sustained economic growth."<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Initially, the oversight board created under <a href="/wiki/PROMESA" title="PROMESA">PROMESA</a> called for Puerto Rico\'s governor <a href="/wiki/Ricardo_Rossell%C3%B3" title="Ricardo Rossell\xc3\xb3">Ricardo Rossell\xc3\xb3</a> to deliver a fiscal turnaround plan by 28 January. Just before that deadline, the control board gave the Commonwealth government until 28 February to present a fiscal plan (including negotiations with creditors for restructuring debt) to solve the problems. A moratorium on lawsuits by debtors was extended to 31 May.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_204-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is essential for Puerto Rico to reach restructuring deals to avoid a bankruptcy-like process under <a href="/wiki/PROMESA" title="PROMESA">PROMESA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An internal survey conducted by the Puerto Rican Economists Association revealed that the majority of Puerto Rican economists reject the policy recommendations of the Board and the Rossell\xc3\xb3 government, with more than 80% of economists arguing in favor of auditing the debt.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In early August 2017, the island\'s financial oversight board (created by PROMESA) planned to institute two days off without pay per month for government employees, down from the original plan of four days per month; the latter had been expected to achieve $218&#160;million in savings. Governor Rossello rejected this plan as unjustified and unnecessary. Pension reforms were also discussed including a proposal for a 10% reduction in benefits to begin addressing the $50&#160;billion in unfunded pension liabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Public_finances">Public finances</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-debt_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico government-debt crisis">Puerto Rico government-debt crisis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Budget of the Government of Puerto Rico">Budget of the Government of Puerto Rico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Public debt of Puerto Rico">public debt of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico has an <a href="/wiki/Operating_budget" title="Operating budget">operating budget</a> of about U.S.$9.8&#160;billion with expenses at about $10.4&#160;billion, creating a structural deficit of $775&#160;million (about 7.9% of the budget).<sup id="cite_ref-el-vocero-la-estadidad-es-uniforme_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-el-vocero-la-estadidad-es-uniforme-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The practice of approving budgets with a structural deficit has been done for 24 consecutive years starting in 2000. Throughout those years, including present time, all budgets contemplated issuing bonds to cover these projected deficits rather than making structural adjustments. This practice increased Puerto Rico\'s cumulative debt, as the government had already been issuing bonds <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government_budget_balance" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico government budget balance">to balance its actual budget</a> for four decades beginning in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>x<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png/400px-Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="323" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png/600px-Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png/800px-Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png 2x" data-file-width="1469" data-file-height="1185" /></a><figcaption>The 2012 Budget of the government of Puerto Rico</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Projected deficits added substantial burdens to an already indebted nation which accrued <a href="/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Public debt of Puerto Rico">a public debt</a> of $71B or about 70% of Puerto Rico\'s gross domestic product. This sparked <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-debt_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico government-debt crisis">an ongoing government-debt crisis</a> after Puerto Rico\'s general obligation bonds were downgraded to speculative non-investment grade ("junk status") by three credit-rating agencies. In terms of financial control, almost 9.6%\xe2\x80\x94or about $1.5&#160;billion\xe2\x80\x94of Puerto Rico\'s central government budget expenses for FY2014 is expected to be spent on debt service.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>y<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Harsher budget cuts are expected as Puerto Rico must now repay larger chunks of debts in the coming years.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (July 2016)">needs update</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>\n</p><p>For practical reasons the budget is divided into two aspects: a "general budget" which comprises the assignments funded exclusively by the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Treasury_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of Treasury of Puerto Rico">Department of Treasury of Puerto Rico</a>, and the "consolidated budget" which comprises the assignments funded by the general budget, by <a href="/wiki/List_of_government-owned_corporations_of_Puerto_Rico" title="List of government-owned corporations of Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico\'s government-owned corporations</a>, by revenue expected from loans, by the sale of government bonds, by subsidies extended by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">federal government of the United States</a>, and by other funds.\n</p><p>Both budgets contrast each other drastically, with the consolidated budget being usually thrice the size of the general budget; currently $29B and $9.0B respectively. Almost one out of every four dollars in the consolidated budget comes from U.S. federal subsidies while government-owned corporations compose more than 31% of the consolidated budget.\n</p><p>The critical aspects come from the sale of bonds, which comprise 7% of the consolidated budget \xe2\x80\x93 a ratio that increased annually due to the government\'s inability to prepare a balanced budget in addition to being incapable of generating enough income to cover all its expenses. In particular, the government-owned corporations add a heavy burden to the overall budget and public debt, as none is self-sufficient. For example, in FY2011 the government-owned corporations reported aggregated losses of more than $1.3B with the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Highways_and_Transportation_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Highways and Transportation Authority">Puerto Rico Highways and Transportation Authority</a> (PRHTA) reporting losses of $409M, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Electric_Power_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority">Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority</a> (PREPA; the government monopoly that controls all electricity on the island) reporting losses of $272M, while the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Aqueducts_and_Sewers_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority">Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority</a> (PRASA; the government monopoly that controls all water utilities on the island) reported losses of $112M.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Losses by government-owned corporations have been defrayed through the issuance of bonds compounding more than 40% of Puerto Rico\'s entire public debt today.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Holistically, from FY2000\xe2\x80\x93FY2010 Puerto Rico\'s debt grew at a <a href="/wiki/Compound_annual_growth_rate" title="Compound annual growth rate">compound annual growth rate</a> (CAGR) of 9% while GDP remained stagnant.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This has not always provided a long-term solution. In early July 2017 for example, the PREPA power authority was effectively bankrupt after defaulting in a plan to restructure $9&#160;billion in bond debt; the agency planned to seek Court protection.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cost_of_living">Cost of living</h3></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png/350px-Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="215" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png/525px-Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png/700px-Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png 2x" data-file-width="837" data-file-height="515" /></a><figcaption>A map of the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920" title="Merchant Marine Act of 1920">Jones Act</a> merchant marine shipping routes for Puerto Rico</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cost_of_living" title="Cost of living">cost of living</a> in Puerto Rico is high and has increased over the past decade.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>z<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>198<span
