class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Statistics used for cost of living sometimes do not take into account certain costs, such as the high cost of electricity, which has hovered in the 24\xc2\xa2 to 30\xc2\xa2 range per kilowatt-hour, two to three times the national average, increased travel costs for longer flights, additional shipping fees, and the loss of promotional participation opportunities for customers "outside the continental United States". While some online stores do offer free shipping on orders to Puerto Rico, many merchants exclude Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories.\n</p><p>The household median income is stated as $19,350 and the mean income as $30,463 in the U.S. Census Bureau\'s 2015 update. The report also indicates that 45.5% of individuals are below the poverty level.<sup id="cite_ref-census1_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census1-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The median home value in Puerto Rico ranges from U.S.$100,000 to U.S.$214,000, while the national median home value sits at $119,600.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>aa<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg/220px-Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg/330px-Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg/440px-Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4500" data-file-height="3000" /></a><figcaption>Flying into San Juan</figcaption></figure>\n<p>One of the most cited contributors to the high cost of living in Puerto Rico is the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920" title="Merchant Marine Act of 1920">Merchant Marine Act of 1920</a>, also known as the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920" title="Merchant Marine Act of 1920">Jones Act</a>, which prevents foreign-flagged ships from carrying cargo between two American ports, a practice known as <a href="/wiki/Cabotage" title="Cabotage">cabotage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-erg-trade_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-erg-trade-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Because of the Jones Act, foreign ships inbound with goods from <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> cannot stop in Puerto Rico, offload Puerto Rico-bound goods, load mainland-bound Puerto Rico-manufactured goods, and continue to U.S. ports. Instead, they must proceed directly to U.S. ports, where distributors <a href="/wiki/Break_bulk_cargo" class="mw-redirect" title="Break bulk cargo">break bulk</a> and send Puerto Rico-bound manufactured goods to Puerto Rico across the ocean by U.S.-flagged ships.<sup id="cite_ref-erg-trade_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-erg-trade-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Government of Puerto Rico">local government of Puerto Rico</a> has requested several times to the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Congress">U.S. Congress</a> to exclude Puerto Rico from the Jones Act restrictions without success.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>ab<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2013 the <a href="/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office" title="Government Accountability Office">Government Accountability Office</a> published a report which concluded that "repealing or amending the Jones Act cabotage law might cut Puerto Rico shipping costs" and that "shippers believed that opening the trade to non-U.S.-flag competition could lower costs".<sup id="cite_ref-joc-gao-report-repeal-quote_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-joc-gao-report-repeal-quote-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>ac<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-joc-gao-report-lower-costs-quote_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-joc-gao-report-lower-costs-quote-237"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>ad<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ultimately, the report concluded that "[the] effects of modifying the application of the Jones Act for Puerto Rico are highly uncertain" for both Puerto Rico and the U.S., particularly for the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Merchant_Marine" title="United States Merchant Marine">U.S. shipping industry</a> and the military preparedness of the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-joc-gao-report_235-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-joc-gao-report-235"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gao-report-pdf_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gao-report-pdf-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A 2018 study by economists at Boston-based Reeve &amp; Associates and Puerto Rico-based Estudios Tecnicos has concluded that the <a href="/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920" title="Merchant Marine Act of 1920">1920 Jones Act</a> has no impact on either retail prices or the cost of living on Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Transportation">Transportation</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Transportation in Puerto Rico">Transportation in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg/350px-Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg/525px-Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg/700px-Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="675" data-file-height="283" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/List_of_highways_in_Puerto_Rico" title="List of highways in Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico interstate highways</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Cities and towns in Puerto Rico are interconnected by a system of roads, <a href="/wiki/Freeway" class="mw-redirect" title="Freeway">freeways</a>, <a href="/wiki/Limited-access_road" title="Limited-access road">expressways</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Highway" title="Highway">highways</a> maintained by the Highways and Transportation Authority under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Transportation" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Department of Transportation">U.S. Department of Transportation</a>, and patrolled by the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Police_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico Police Department">Puerto Rico Police Department</a>. The island\'s <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="San Juan metropolitan area">San Juan metropolitan area</a> is served by a <a href="/wiki/Autoridad_Metropolitana_de_Autobuses" class="mw-redirect" title="Autoridad Metropolitana de Autobuses">public bus transit system</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">metro system</a> called <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Tren_Urbano" title="Tren Urbano">Tren Urbano</a></i></span> (\'Urban Train\'). Other forms of Puerto Rican public transport include seaborne ferries that serve Puerto Rico\'s archipelago as well as <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">carros p\xc3\xbablicos</i></span> (<a href="/wiki/Share_taxi" title="Share taxi">private mini buses</a>).\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has three <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">international airports</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Luis_Mu%C3%B1oz_Mar%C3%ADn_International_Airport" title="Luis Mu\xc3\xb1oz Mar\xc3\xadn International Airport">Luis Mu\xc3\xb1oz Mar\xc3\xadn International Airport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Carolina,_Puerto_Rico" title="Carolina, Puerto Rico">Carolina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercedita_International_Airport" title="Mercedita International Airport">Mercedita International Airport</a> in Ponce, and the <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Hern%C3%A1ndez_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Rafael Hern\xc3\xa1ndez International Airport">Rafael Hern\xc3\xa1ndez International Airport</a> in Aguadilla, and 27 local airports. The Luis Mu\xc3\xb1oz Mar\xc3\xadn International Airport is the largest aerial transportation hub in the Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-PRPA2008-07-28_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRPA2008-07-28-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_(Puerto_Rico).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg/220px-Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg/330px-Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg/440px-Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a><figcaption>A <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Tren_Urbano" title="Tren Urbano">Tren Urbano</a></i></span> train at Bayam\xc3\xb3n Station</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rico has nine <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">ports</a> in different cities across the main island. The <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Port" class="mw-redirect" title="San Juan Port">San Juan Port</a> is the largest in Puerto Rico, and the busiest port in the Caribbean and the 10th busiest in the United States in terms of commercial activity and cargo movement, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-PRPA2008-07-28_240-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRPA2008-07-28-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The second largest port is the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_the_Americas" class="mw-redirect" title="Port of the Americas">Port of the Americas</a> in Ponce, currently under expansion to increase cargo capacity to <span class="nowrap">1.5 million</span> twenty-foot containers (<a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">TEUs</a>) per year.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Utilities">Utilities</h3></div>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Electricity">Electricity</h4></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Electric_Power_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority">Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Electric_Power_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority">Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority</a> (PREPA, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">Autoridad de Energ\xc3\xada El\xc3\xa9ctrica, AEE</i>)\xe2\x80\x94is an <a href="/wiki/Electric_power_company" class="mw-redirect" title="Electric power company">electric power company</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_government-owned_corporations_of_Puerto_Rico" title="List of government-owned corporations of Puerto Rico">government-owned corporation of Puerto Rico</a> responsible for <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">electricity generation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electric_power_transmission" title="Electric power transmission">power transmission</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electric_power_distribution" title="Electric power distribution">power distribution</a> in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> PREPA was, by law, the only entity authorized to conduct such business in Puerto Rico, effectively making it a <a href="/wiki/Government_monopoly" class="mw-redirect" title="Government monopoly">government monopoly</a> until 2018. The Authority is ruled by a governing board appointed by the governor with the <a href="/wiki/Advice_and_consent" title="Advice and consent">advice and consent</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Senate of Puerto Rico">Senate of Puerto Rico</a>, and is run by an executive director.\n</p><p>On 20 July 2018, Puerto Rico Law 120-2018 (<span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Ley para Transformar el Sistema El\xc3\xa9ctrico de Puerto Rico</i></span>) was signed. This law authorized PREPA to sell infrastructure and services to other providers. As a result, a contract was signed on 22 June 2020, making <a href="/wiki/LUMA_Energy" title="LUMA Energy">LUMA Energy</a> the new operator of the energy distribution and transmission infrastructure, as well as other areas of PREPA\'s operations, in effect partially privatizing the Puerto Rican power grid. The takeover was set for 1 June 2021, amidst protests and uncertainty from the point of view of the general public and the former-PREPA workers and <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">union members</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Water_and_sewage">Water and sewage</h4></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Aqueducts_and_Sewers_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority">Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority</a></div>\n<p>Similarly, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Aqueducts_and_Sewers_Authority" title="Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority">Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority</a> (PRASA, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i lang="es">Autoridad de Acueductos y Alcantarillados, AAA</i>)\xe2\x80\x94is a water company and the government-owned corporation responsible for <a href="/wiki/Water_quality" title="Water quality">water quality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_resource_management" class="mw-redirect" title="Water resource management">management</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">supply</a> in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is the only entity authorized to conduct such business in Puerto Rico, effectively making it a government monopoly. Its existence is designated by Law No. 40 of 1 May 1945, including the corresponding amendments.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Communications in Puerto Rico">Communications in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Telecommunications in Puerto Rico includes radio, television, fixed and mobile telephones, and the Internet. Broadcasting in Puerto Rico is regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission" title="Federal Communications Commission">U.S. Federal Communications Commission</a> (FCC).<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, there were 30 TV stations, 125 radio stations and roughly 1&#160;million TV sets on the island. Cable TV subscription services are available, and the U.S. Armed Forces Radio and Television Service also broadcast on the island.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAWFB-PuertoRico-2013_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAWFB-PuertoRico-2013-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico also has its own <a href="/wiki/Amateur_radio" title="Amateur radio">amateur radio prefixes</a>, which differ from those of the contiguous United States in that there are two letter before the number. The most well-known prefix is KP4, but others separated for use on the <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> (including Desecheo and Mona) are: KP3/KP4/NP3/NP4/WP3/WP4 (Puerto Rico, <a href="/wiki/Vieques,_Puerto_Rico" title="Vieques, Puerto Rico">Vieques</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culebra,_Puerto_Rico" title="Culebra, Puerto Rico">Culebra</a>) and KP5/NP5/WP5 (<a href="/wiki/Desecheo_Island" title="Desecheo Island">Desecheo Island</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Amateur radio operators (also known as ham radio operators) are a well-known group in the island and can obtain special vehicle license plates with their callsign on them.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They have been a key element in disaster relief.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demographics">Demographics</h2></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1224496135">.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop{border-spacing:1px;border:1px solid #a2a9b1;background-color:var(--background-color-neutral-subtle,#f8f9fa);padding:0.3em;font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop caption{background-color:lavender;color:black;padding-right:0.2em;padding-left:0.2em;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold;border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-bottom:none}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop th[scope=col]{border-bottom:1px solid black}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop td:nth-child(2){text-align:right;padding-left:0.5em;padding-right:0}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop td.us-census-pop-estimate{padding-left:0}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop td:nth-child(3){padding-left:0}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop td:nth-child(4){padding-left:0.5em;text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop-footnote{border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:center}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop-right{float:right;clear:right;margin:0 0 1em 1em}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop-left{float:left;clear:left;margin:0 1em 1em 0}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}.mw-parser-output .us-census-pop-none{float:none;margin:0 1em 1em 0}}</style>\n<table class="us-census-pop 1900)<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Census2020-Tab2_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2020-Tab2-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Demographics of Puerto Rico">Demographics of Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_diversity_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Cultural diversity in Puerto Rico">Cultural diversity in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The population of Puerto Rico has been shaped by initial <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Amerindian settlement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">European colonization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a>, economic migration, and Puerto Rico\'s status as unincorporated territory of the United States.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Population_distribution">Population distribution</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Puerto Rico">List of cities in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The most populous municipality is the capital, <a href="/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico" title="San Juan, Puerto Rico">San Juan</a>, with 342,259 people based on the <a href="/wiki/2020_United_States_census" title="2020 United States census">2020 Census</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Bayam%C3%B3n,_Puerto_Rico" title="Bayam\xc3\xb3n, Puerto Rico">Bayam\xc3\xb3n</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carolina,_Puerto_Rico" title="Carolina, Puerto Rico">Carolina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Caguas,_Puerto_Rico" title="Caguas, Puerto Rico">Caguas</a>. Of the ten most populous cities on the island, eight are located within what is considered <a href="/wiki/San_Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo metropolitan area">San Juan\'s metropolitan area</a>, while the other two are located in the south (<a href="/wiki/Ponce_metropolitan_area" title="Ponce metropolitan area">Ponce</a>) and west (<a href="/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez_metropolitan_area" title="Mayag\xc3\xbcez metropolitan area">Mayag\xc3\xbcez</a>) of the island.\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1219497266">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9;color:#222}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0;color:#222}</style>\n<div>\n<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray;">\n\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0.75em;"><div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">&#160;</div><div style="float:left; width:6em; height:2.6em">&#160;</div> style="text-align:right;">89,780\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">7</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Arecibo" class="mw-redirect" title="Arecibo">Arecibo</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/San_Juan%E2%80%93Caguas%E2%80%93Guaynabo_metropolitan_area" title="San Juan\xe2\x80\x93Caguas\xe2\x80\x93Guaynabo metropolitan area">San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">87,754\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">8</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Toa_Baja" class="mw-redirect" title="Toa Baja">Toa Baja</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/San_Juan%E2%80%93Caguas%E2%80%93Guaynabo_metropolitan_area" title="San Juan\xe2\x80\x93Caguas\xe2\x80\x93Guaynabo metropolitan area">San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">75,293\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">9</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayag\xc3\xbcez">Mayag\xc3\xbcez</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez_metropolitan_area" title="Mayag\xc3\xbcez metropolitan area">Mayag\xc3\xbcez</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">73,077\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">10</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Trujillo_Alto" class="mw-redirect" title="Trujillo Alto">Trujillo Alto</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/San_Juan%E2%80%93Caguas%E2%80%93Guaynabo_metropolitan_area" title="San Juan\xe2\x80\x93Caguas\xe2\x80\x93Guaynabo metropolitan area">San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:right;">67,740\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table></div>\n<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Population_makeup">Population makeup</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans" title="Puerto Ricans">Puerto Ricans</a></div>\n<div class="notheme barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">\n<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white; color: black;">\n<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">\n<tbody><tr style="background:none"><th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Racial and Ethnic Composition in Puerto Rico (2020 Census)<sup id="cite_ref-2020CensusData_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2020CensusData-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></th></tr>\n<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">\n<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Ethnicity</td>\n<td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/White_Puerto_Ricans" title="White Puerto Ricans">White</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:AntiqueWhite; width:17.1%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">17.1%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Afro-Puerto_Ricans" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Puerto Ricans">Black</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Black; width:7.0%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">7.0%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Asian_Puerto_Ricans" title="Asian Puerto Ricans">Asian</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Yellow; width:0.1%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.1%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Multiracial_Americans" title="Multiracial Americans">Two or more races</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Tan; width:49.8%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">49.8%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">American Indian</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Red; width:0.5%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.5%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander_Americans" title="Pacific Islander Americans">Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander</a></td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Orange; width:0.0%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.0%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other races</td>\n<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:#9999FF; width:25.5%; overflow: hidden;">&#8201;</div></td>\n<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 1.2em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">25.5%</td>\n</tr>\n\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Puerto Rico was 98.9% Hispanic or Latino in 2020, of that 95.5% were <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans" title="Puerto Ricans">Puerto Rican</a> and 3.4% were Hispanic of non-Puerto Rican origins. Only 1.1% of the population was non-Hispanic.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The population of Puerto Rico according to the 2020 census was 3,285,874, an 11.8% decrease since the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Census" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 United States Census">2010 United States Census</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2020-Tab2_24-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2020-Tab2-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The commonwealth\'s population peaked in 2000, when it was 3,808,610, before declining (for the first time in census history) to 3,725,789 in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Wall_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wall-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Emigration due to economic difficulties and natural disasters, coupled with a low birth rate, have caused the population decline to continue in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Censuses of Puerto Rico were completed by Spain in 1765, 1775, 1800, 1815, 1832, 1846 and 1857, yet some of the data remained untabulated and was not considered reliable according to <a href="/wiki/Irene_Barnes_Taeuber" title="Irene Barnes Taeuber">Irene Barnes Taeuber</a>, an American demographer who worked for the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Population_Research" title="Office of Population Research">Office of Population Research</a> at <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Taeuber_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taeuber-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Continuous European immigration and high <a href="/wiki/Natural_increase" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural increase">natural increase</a> helped the population of Puerto Rico grow from 155,426 in 1800 to almost a million by the close of the 19th century. A census conducted by royal decree on 30 September 1858, gave the following totals of the Puerto Rican population at that time: 341,015 were <a href="/wiki/Free_people_of_color" title="Free people of color">free colored</a>; 300,430 were <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">white</a>; and 41,736 were <a href="/wiki/Slaves" class="mw-redirect" title="Slaves">slaves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A census in 1887 found a population of around 800,000, of which 320,000 were black.<sup id="cite_ref-Trove_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trove-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png/220px-Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="177" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png/330px-Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png/440px-Puerto_Rico_single_age_population_pyramid_2020.png 2x" data-file-width="2212" data-file-height="1777" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Demographics of Puerto Rico">Population age pyramid</a> of Puerto Rico in 2020.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>During the 19th century, hundreds of families arrived in Puerto Rico, primarily from the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a>, but also from other parts of Spain such as <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asturias" title="Asturias">Asturias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">Galicia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">Balearic Islands</a> and numerous Spanish loyalists from Spain\'s former colonies in South America. Settlers from outside Spain also arrived in the islands, including from <a href="/wiki/Corsica" title="Corsica">Corsica</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="Irish immigration to Puerto Rico">Ireland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="German immigration to Puerto Rico">Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian people">Italy</a>. This immigration from non-Hispanic countries was the result of the <i>Real C\xc3\xa9dula de Gracias de 1815</i> (<a href="/wiki/Royal_Decree_of_Graces_of_1815" title="Royal Decree of Graces of 1815">Royal Decree of Graces of 1815</a>), which allowed European Catholics to settle in the island with land allotments in the interior of the island, provided they paid taxes and continued to support the Catholic Church.\n</p><p>Between 1960 and 1990, the census questionnaire in Puerto Rico did not ask about race or ethnicity. The <a href="/wiki/2000_United_States_Census" class="mw-redirect" title="2000 United States Census">2000 United States Census</a> included a racial self-identification question in Puerto Rico. According to the census, most Puerto Ricans identified as white and Latino; few identified as black or some other race.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Literacy">Literacy</h4></div>\n<p>A <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research</a> survey indicated an adult literacy rate of 90.4% in 2012 based on data from the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto3_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Life_expectancy">Life expectancy</h4></div>\n<p>Puerto Rico has a life expectancy of approximately 82.1 years according to the CIA World Factbook, an improvement from 78.7 years in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Immigration_and_emigration">Immigration and emigration</h3></div>\n<table style="float:center;" class="wikitable">\n\n<tbody><tr>\n<td colspan="7" style="text-align: center;">Racial groups\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Year</th>\n<th>Population</th>\n<th>White</th>\n<th>Mixed (mainly biracial white European and black African)</th>\n<th>Black</th>\n<th>Asian</th>\n<th>Other\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>2000\n</td>\n<td>3,808,610\n</td>\n<td>80.5% (3,064,862)\n</td>\n<td>11.0% (418,426)\n</td>\n<td>8.0% (302,933)\n</td>\n<td>0.2% (7,960)\n</td>\n<td>0.4% (14,429)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>2010\n</td>\n<td>3,725,789\n</td>\n<td>75.8% (2,824,148)\n</td>\n<td>11.1% (413,563)\n</td>\n<td>12.4% (461,998)\n</td>\n<td>0.2% (7,452)\n</td>\n<td>0.6% (22,355)\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td>2016\n</td>\n<td>3,195,153\n</td>\n<td>68.9% (2,201,460)\n</td>\n<td>n/a (n/a)\n</td>\n<td>9.8% (313,125)\n</td>\n<td>0.2% (6,390)\n</td>\n<td>0.8% (25,561)\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The vast majority of recent immigrants, both legal and illegal, come from <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, over half come from the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="Dominican Republic immigration to Puerto Rico">Dominican Republic</a>. Dominicans represent 53% of non-Puerto Rican Hispanics, about 1.8% of Puerto Rico\'s population.<sup id="cite_ref-refworld.org_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-refworld.org-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some illegal immigrants, particularly from Haiti, Dominican Republic,<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and Cuba<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2023)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>, use Puerto Rico as a temporary stop-over point to get to the U.S. mainland. Other major sources of recent immigrants include <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">Honduras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder.census.gov_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder.census.gov-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, there are many non-Puerto Rican U.S. citizens settling in Puerto Rico from the U.S. mainland, majority of which are <a href="/wiki/Non-Hispanic_Whites" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-Hispanic Whites">White Americans</a> and a smaller number are <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans">Black Americans</a>. In fact, non-hispanic people represent 1.1% and majority of them are from the U.S. mainland. Smaller numbers of U.S. citizens come from the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Virgin_Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Virgin Islands">U.S. Virgin Islands</a>. There are also large numbers of <a href="/wiki/Nuyorican" title="Nuyorican">Nuyoricans</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Stateside_Puerto_Ricans" title="Stateside Puerto Ricans">stateside Puerto Ricans</a> coming back, as many Puerto Ricans engage in \'circular migration\'.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Small numbers of non-Puerto Rican Hispanics in Puerto Rico are actually American-born migrants from the mainland U.S. and not recent immigrants. Most recent immigrants settle in and around the San Juan metropolitan area.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">Emigration</a> is a major part of contemporary Puerto Rican history. Starting soon after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War&#160;II</a>, poverty, cheap airfares, and promotion by the island government caused waves of Puerto Ricans to move to the U.S. mainland, particularly to the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">northeastern states</a> and nearby <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This trend continued even as Puerto Rico\'s economy improved and its birth rate declined. Puerto Ricans continue to follow a pattern of "<a href="/wiki/Circular_migration" title="Circular migration">circular migration</a>", with some migrants returning to the island. In recent years, the population has declined markedly, falling nearly 1% in 2012 and an additional 1% (36,000 people) in 2013 due to a falling birthrate and emigration.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The impact of hurricanes <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Maria" title="Hurricane Maria">Maria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Irma" title="Hurricane Irma">Irma</a> in 2017, combined with the unincorporated territory\'s worsening economy, led to its greatest population decline since the U.S. acquired the archipelago.\n</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/2020_U.S._census" class="mw-redirect" title="2020 U.S. census">2020 U.S. census</a>, the number of Puerto Ricans living outside of Puerto Rico in the U.S. is almost twice as many as those living in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  As those who leave tend to be better educated than those who remain, this accentuates the drain on Puerto Rico\'s economy.\n</p><p>Based on 1 July 2019 estimate by the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Census Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, the population of the Commonwealth had declined by 532,095 people since the 2010 Census data had been tabulated.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Languages">Languages</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Spanish" title="Puerto Rican Spanish">Puerto Rican Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/English_language_in_Puerto_Rico" title="English language in Puerto Rico">English language in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> of the executive branch of government of Puerto Rico<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> are Spanish and English, with Spanish being the primary language. Spanish is, and has been, the only official language of the entire Commonwealth judiciary system, despite a 1902 English-only language law.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, all official business of the <a href="/wiki/U.S._District_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. District Court">U.S. District Court</a> for the District of Puerto Rico is conducted in English. English is the primary language of less than 10% of the population. Spanish is the dominant language of business, education and daily life on the island, spoken by nearly 95% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-factfinder.census.gov2_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder.census.gov2-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Out of people aged five and older, 94.3% speak only Spanish at home, 5.5% speak English, and 0.2% speak other languages.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>In Puerto Rico, public school instruction is conducted almost entirely in Spanish. There have been pilot programs in about a dozen of the over 1,400 public schools aimed at conducting instruction in English only. Objections from teaching staff are common, perhaps because many of them are not fully fluent in English.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> English is taught as a second language and is a compulsory subject from elementary levels to high school. The languages of the deaf community are <a href="/wiki/American_Sign_Language" title="American Sign Language">American Sign Language</a> and its local variant, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Sign_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rican Sign Language">Puerto Rican Sign Language</a>.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Spanish" title="Puerto Rican Spanish">Spanish of Puerto Rico</a> has evolved into having many idiosyncrasies in vocabulary and syntax that differentiate it from the Spanish spoken elsewhere. Puerto Rican Spanish utilizes many <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_language" title="Ta\xc3\xadno language">Ta\xc3\xadno</a> words, as well as English words. The largest influence on the Spanish spoken in Puerto Rico is <a href="/wiki/Canarian_Spanish" title="Canarian Spanish">that of the Canary Islands</a>. Ta\xc3\xadno <a href="/wiki/Loanword" title="Loanword">loanwords</a> are most often used in the context of vegetation, natural phenomena, and native musical instruments. Similarly, words attributed to primarily <a href="/wiki/Niger%E2%80%93Congo_languages" title="Niger\xe2\x80\x93Congo languages">West African languages</a> were adopted in the contexts of foods, music, and dances, particularly in coastal towns with concentrations of descendants of Sub-Saharan Africans.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>\n<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">\n<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">\n<div style="border:solid transparent;background-color:initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Black; z-index:-1"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color:initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 181.89932472811px; border-left-color:Red"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Red"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Red"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color:initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 120.87923504096px; border-left-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DeepSkyBlue"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color:initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:36.812455268468px 92.977648588825px 0 0; border-top-color:Blue"></div>\n<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Blue"></div>\n</div>\n<div class="thumbcaption">\n<p>Religious affiliation in Puerto Rico (2014)<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> (56%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:DeepSkyBlue; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> (33%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Red; color:black;">&#160;</span>&#160;Other (3%)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959"><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Black; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Irreligious" class="mw-redirect" title="Irreligious">Irreligious</a> (8%)</div>\n</div>\n</div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Catholic Church in Puerto Rico">Catholicism</a> was brought by Spanish colonists and gradually became the dominant religion in Puerto Rico. The first <a href="/wiki/Dioceses" class="mw-redirect" title="Dioceses">dioceses</a> in the Americas, including <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_San_Juan_de_Puerto_Rico" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Juan de Puerto Rico">that of Puerto Rico</a>, were authorized by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Julius_II" title="Pope Julius II">Pope Julius&#160;II</a> in 1511.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1512, priests were established for the parochial churches. By 1759, there was a priest for each church.<sup id="cite_ref-Puerto_Rico_Office_of_Historian_1949_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Puerto_Rico_Office_of_Historian_1949-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> One Pope, <a href="/wiki/John_Paul_II" class="mw-redirect" title="John Paul II">John Paul&#160;II</a>, visited Puerto Rico in October 1984. All <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Municipalities of Puerto Rico">municipalities</a> in Puerto Rico have at least one Catholic church, most of which are located at the town center, or <a href="/wiki/Plaza" class="mw-redirect" title="Plaza">plaza</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Protestantism in Puerto Rico">Protestantism</a>, which was suppressed under the Spanish Catholic regime, has reemerged under U.S. rule, making contemporary Puerto Rico more interconfessional than in previous centuries, although Catholicism continues to be the dominant religion. The first Protestant church, <a href="/wiki/Iglesia_de_la_Sant%C3%ADsima_Trinidad" title="Iglesia de la Sant\xc3\xadsima Trinidad">Iglesia de la Sant\xc3\xadsima Trinidad</a>, was established in Ponce by the <a href="/wiki/Anglican" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglican">Anglican</a> <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Antigua" class="mw-redirect" title="Diocese of Antigua">Diocese of Antigua</a> in 1872.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was the first non-Catholic church in the entire <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Americas" class="mw-redirect" title="The Americas">the Americas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Pollster Pablo Ramos stated in 1998 that the population was 38% Roman Catholic, 28% Pentecostal, and 18% were members of independent churches, which would give a Protestant percentage of 46% if the last two populations are combined. Protestants collectively added up to almost two million people. Another researcher gave a more conservative assessment of the proportion of Protestants:\n</p>\n<blockquote><p>Puerto Rico, by virtue of its long political association with the United States, is the most Protestant of Latin American countries, with a Protestant population of approximately 33 to 38 percent, the majority of whom are <a href="/wiki/Pentecostal" class="mw-redirect" title="Pentecostal">Pentecostal</a>. David Stoll calculates that if we extrapolate the growth rates of evangelical churches from 1960 to 1985 for another twenty-five years Puerto Rico will become 75 percent evangelical. (Ana Adams: "Brincando el Charco..." in <i>Power, Politics and Pentecostals in Latin America</i>, Edward Cleary, ed., 1997. p.&#160;164).<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></p></blockquote>\n<p>An <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a> article in March 2014 stated that "more than 70 percent of whom identify themselves as Catholic" but provided no source for this information.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> reports that 85% of the population of Puerto Rico identifies as Roman Catholic, while 15% identify as Protestant and Other. Neither a date or a source for that information is provided and may not be recent.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A 2013 Pew Research survey found that only about 45% of Puerto Rican adults identified themselves as Catholic, 29% as Protestant and 20% as unaffiliated with a religion. The people surveyed by Pew consisted of Puerto Ricans living in the 50 states and DC and may not be indicative of those living in the Commonwealth.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg/220px-Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg/330px-Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg/440px-Catedral_de_San_Juan_Bautista_a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1944" data-file-height="2592" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Catedral_Metropolitana_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_San_Juan_Bautista" class="mw-redirect" title="Catedral Metropolitana Bas\xc3\xadlica de San Juan Bautista">Cathedral of San Juan</a>, built between 1535 and 1802.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>By 2014, a Pew Research report, with the sub-title <i>Widespread Change in a Historically Catholic Region</i>, indicated that only 56% of Puerto Ricans were Catholic, 33% were Protestant, and 8% were unaffiliated; this survey was completed between October 2013 and February 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>An <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> community, the Dormition of the Most Holy Theotokos / St. Spyridon\'s Church is located in Trujillo Alto, and serves the small Orthodox community in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2017, the church entered communion with the Roman Catholic Church, becoming the first <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Catholic Church">Eastern Catholic Church</a> in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This affiliation accounted for under 1% of the population in 2010 according to the Pew Research report.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are two <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Churches</a> in the territory; the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church_Outside_of_Russia" title="Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia">Russian Orthodox</a> <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">Mission</a> Saint John Climacus in <a href="/wiki/San_Germ%C3%A1n,_Puerto_Rico" title="San Germ\xc3\xa1n, Puerto Rico">San German</a> and the Saint George <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Patriarchate_of_Antioch" title="Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Antioch">Antiochian Orthodox Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/Carolina,_Puerto_Rico" title="Carolina, Puerto Rico">Carolina</a>. Both have services in English and Spanish.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>There is a small <a href="/wiki/Syriac_Orthodox_Church" title="Syriac Orthodox Church">Syriac</a> Orthodox church in <a href="/wiki/Aguada,_Puerto_Rico" title="Aguada, Puerto Rico">Aguada</a> which is also the only <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_Churches" title="Oriental Orthodox Churches">Oriental Orthodox</a> in the Island and serves a small growing community in the area. In 1940, <a href="/wiki/Juanita_Garc%C3%ADa_Peraza" title="Juanita Garc\xc3\xada Peraza">Juanita Garc\xc3\xada Peraza</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Mita_Congregation" title="Mita Congregation">Mita Congregation</a>, the first religion of Puerto Rican origin.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Ta\xc3\xadno people">Ta\xc3\xadno religious practices</a> have been rediscovered/reinvented to a degree by a handful of advocates.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Similarly, some aspects of African religious traditions have been kept by some adherents. African slaves brought and maintained various ethnic African religious practices associated with different peoples; in particular, the <a href="/wiki/Yoruba_religion" title="Yoruba religion">Yoruba</a> beliefs of <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santer\xc3\xada">Santer\xc3\xada</a> or <a href="/wiki/If%C3%A1" title="If\xc3\xa1">If\xc3\xa1</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Kongo_people" title="Kongo people">Kongo</a>-derived <a href="/wiki/Palo_Mayombe" class="mw-redirect" title="Palo Mayombe">Palo Mayombe</a>. Some aspects were absorbed into syncretic Christianity. In 1952, a handful of <a href="/wiki/American_Jews" title="American Jews">American Jews</a> established the island\'s first <a href="/wiki/Synagogue" title="Synagogue">synagogue</a>; this religion accounts for under 1% of the population in 2010 according to the Pew Research report.<sup id="cite_ref-EG_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EG-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The synagogue, called <i>Sha\'are Zedeck</i>, hired its first rabbi in 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-JVL_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JVL-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Puerto Rico has the largest Jewish community in the Caribbean, numbering 3000 people,<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and is the only Caribbean island in which the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Conservative Jews">Conservative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reform_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Reform Jews">Reform</a> and <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Jews">Orthodox Jewish</a> movements all are represented.<sup id="cite_ref-JVL_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JVL-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LN_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LN-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2007, there were about 5,000 <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a> in Puerto Rico, representing about 0.13% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Eight <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">mosques</a> are located throughout the island, with most Muslims living in <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Piedras" class="mw-redirect" title="R\xc3\xado Piedras">R\xc3\xado Piedras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caguas" class="mw-redirect" title="Caguas">Caguas</a>; most Muslims are of Palestinian and Jordanian descent.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There is also a <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bah\xc3\xa1\xca\xbc\xc3\xad Faith">Bah\xc3\xa1\xca\xbc\xc3\xad</a> community.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, <a href="/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints" title="The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints">the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> dedicated a <a href="/wiki/Temple_(LDS_Church)" title="Temple (LDS Church)">temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_Puerto_Rico_Temple" title="San Juan Puerto Rico Temple">San Juan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and reported having a membership of approximately 23,000 in the commonwealth.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2015, the 25,832 <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah\'s Witnesses</a> represented about 0.70% of the population, with 324 congregations.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Buddhism in Puerto Rico is represented with <a href="/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism" title="Nichiren Buddhism">Nichiren</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Khenchen_Palden_Sherab_Rinpoche" title="Khenchen Palden Sherab Rinpoche">New York Padmasambhava Buddhist Center</a> for example having a branch in San Juan.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are several atheist activist and educational organizations, and an atheistic parody religion called the <a href="/wiki/Pastafarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Pastafarian">Pastafarian</a> Church of Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/International_Society_for_Krishna_Consciousness" title="International Society for Krishna Consciousness">ISKCON</a> temple in Gurabo is devoted to <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a>, with two preaching centers in the San Juan metropolitan area.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Education in Puerto Rico">Education in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The first school in Puerto Rico was the <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Escuela de Gram\xc3\xa1tica</i></span> (Grammar School). It was established by Bishop <a href="/wiki/Alonso_Manso" title="Alonso Manso">Alonso Manso</a> in 1513, in the area where the <a href="/wiki/Catedral_Metropolitana_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_San_Juan_Bautista" class="mw-redirect" title="Catedral Metropolitana Bas\xc3\xadlica de San Juan Bautista">Cathedral of San Juan</a> was to be constructed. The school was free of charge and the courses taught were <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin language</a>, literature, history, science, art, philosophy and theology.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Education in Puerto Rico is divided in three levels\xe2\x80\x94Primary (elementary school grades 1\xe2\x80\x936), Secondary (intermediate and high school grades 7\xe2\x80\x9312), and Higher Level (undergraduate and graduate studies). As of 2002, the literacy rate of the Puerto Rican population was 94.1%; by gender, it was 93.9% for males and 94.4% for females.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the 2000 Census, 60.0% of the population attained a high school degree or higher level of education, and 18.3% has a bachelor\'s degree or higher.\n</p><p>Instruction at the primary school level is compulsory between the ages of 5 and 18. As of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, there are 1539 public schools and 806 private schools.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>The largest and oldest university system is the public <a href="/wiki/University_of_Puerto_Rico" title="University of Puerto Rico">University of Puerto Rico</a> (UPR) with 11 campuses. The largest private university systems on the island are the <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Sistema_Universitario_Ana_G._Mendez" class="mw-redirect" title="Sistema Universitario Ana G. Mendez">Sistema Universitario Ana G. Mendez</a></span></span> which operates the <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/University_of_Turabo" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Turabo">Universidad del Turabo</a></span></span>, <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_University_(Puerto_Rico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Metropolitan University (Puerto Rico)">Metropolitan University</a> and <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Universidad_del_Este" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad del Este">Universidad del Este</a></span></span>. Other private universities include the multi-campus <a href="/wiki/Inter_American_University_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Inter American University of Puerto Rico">Inter American University</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_University_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic University of Puerto Rico">Pontifical Catholic University</a>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Polytechnic_University_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Polytechnic University of Puerto Rico">Universidad Polit\xc3\xa9cnica de Puerto Rico</a></span></span>, and the <span title="Spanish-language text"><span lang="es" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Sacred_Heart_(Puerto_Rico)" class="mw-redirect" title="University of the Sacred Heart (Puerto Rico)">Universidad del Sagrado Coraz\xc3\xb3n</a></span></span>. Puerto Rico has four schools of Medicine and three <a href="/wiki/American_Bar_Association" title="American Bar Association">ABA</a>-approved Law Schools.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health">Health</h3></div>\n<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero,_Ponce,_Puerto_Rico_(IMG_2923).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg/200px-Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="267" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg/300px-Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg/400px-Old_Dr._Pila_Hospital_in_Barrio_Primero%2C_Ponce%2C_Puerto_Rico_%28IMG_2923%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="1024" /></a><figcaption>Old Hospital Doctor Pila in Barrio Primero, <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce</a> city.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>In 2017, there were 69 hospitals in Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Reforma de Salud de Puerto Rico</i></span> (<a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Health_Reform" title="Puerto Rico Health Reform">Puerto Rico Health Reform</a>) \xe2\x80\x93 locally referred to as <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">La Reforma</i></span> (\'The Reform\') \xe2\x80\x93 is a government-run program which provides medical and health care services to the indigent and <a href="/wiki/Impoverished" class="mw-redirect" title="Impoverished">impoverished</a>, by means of contracting private <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance" title="Health insurance">health insurance</a> companies, rather than employing government-owned hospitals and emergency centers. The Reform is administered by the Puerto Rico Health Insurance Administration.<sup id="cite_ref-Form_10K_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Form_10K-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Culture of Puerto Rico">Culture of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>Modern Puerto Rican culture is a unique mix of cultural antecedents: including European (predominantly Spanish, <a href="/wiki/Corsican_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="Corsican immigration to Puerto Rico">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="French immigration to Puerto Rico">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="German immigration to Puerto Rico">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irish_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico" title="Irish immigration to Puerto Rico">Irish</a>), African, and, more recently, some North American and many South Americans. Many Cubans and Dominicans have relocated to the island in the past few decades.\n</p><p>From the Spanish, Puerto Rico received the Spanish language, the <a href="/wiki/Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic">Catholic</a> religion and the vast majority of their cultural and moral values and traditions. The United States added English-language influence, the university system and the adoption of some holidays and practices. On 12 March 1903, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Puerto_Rico" title="University of Puerto Rico">University of Puerto Rico</a> was officially founded, branching out from the "Escuela Normal Industrial", a smaller organization that was founded in Fajardo three years earlier.\n</p><p>Much of Puerto Rican culture centers on the influence of music and has been shaped by other cultures combining with local and traditional rhythms. Early in the history of Puerto Rican music, the influences of Spanish and African traditions were most noticeable. The cultural movements across the Caribbean and North America have played a vital role in the more recent musical influences which have reached Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has many symbols, but only the <a href="/wiki/Thespesia_grandiflora" title="Thespesia grandiflora">Flor de Maga</a> has been made official by the Government of Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other popular, traditional, or unofficial symbols of Puerto Rico are the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_spindalis" title="Puerto Rican spindalis">Puerto Rican
