spindalis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ceiba_pentandra" title="Ceiba pentandra">kapok tree</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Coqu%C3%AD" title="Coqu\xc3\xad">coqu\xc3\xad frog</a>, the <a href="/wiki/J%C3%ADbaro_(Puerto_Rico)" title="J\xc3\xadbaro (Puerto Rico)">j\xc3\xadbaro</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Ta\xc3\xadno">Ta\xc3\xadno Indian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cerro_Las_Tetas" title="Cerro Las Tetas">Cerro Las Tetas</a> with its <a href="/wiki/Monumento_al_J%C3%ADbaro_Puertorrique%C3%B1o" title="Monumento al J\xc3\xadbaro Puertorrique\xc3\xb1o">j\xc3\xadbaro culture monument</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Architecture">Architecture</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Architecture of Puerto Rico">Architecture of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The architecture of Puerto Rico demonstrates a broad variety of traditions, styles and national influences accumulated over four centuries of Spanish rule, and a century of American rule. <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonial_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish colonial architecture">Spanish colonial architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Ibero-Islamic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_deco" class="mw-redirect" title="Art deco">art deco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Post-modern_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-modern architecture">post-modern</a>, and many other architectural forms are visible throughout the island. From town to town, there are also many regional distinctions.\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_(28488284470).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg/220px-The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg/330px-The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg/440px-The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000" /></a><figcaption>Street-lined homes in <a href="/wiki/Old_San_Juan" title="Old San Juan">Old San Juan</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Old San Juan is one of the two <i>barrios</i>, in addition to <a href="/wiki/Santurce,_San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico" title="Santurce, San Juan, Puerto Rico">Santurce</a>, that made up the <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipality</a> of San Juan from 1864 to 1951, at which time the former independent municipality of <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Piedras" class="mw-redirect" title="R\xc3\xado Piedras">R\xc3\xado Piedras</a> was annexed. With its abundance of shops, historic places, museums, open air caf\xc3\xa9s, restaurants, gracious homes, tree-shaded plazas, and its old beauty and architectonical peculiarity, Old San Juan is a main spot for local and internal tourism. The district is also characterized by numerous public plazas and churches including <a href="/wiki/San_Jos%C3%A9_Church" title="San Jos\xc3\xa9 Church">San Jos\xc3\xa9 Church</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Catedral_Metropolitana_Bas%C3%ADlica_de_San_Juan_Bautista_(San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico)" class="mw-redirect" title="Catedral Metropolitana Bas\xc3\xadlica de San Juan Bautista (San Juan, Puerto Rico)">Cathedral of San Juan Bautista</a>, which contains the tomb of the Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n" title="Juan Ponce de Le\xc3\xb3n">Juan Ponce de Le\xc3\xb3n</a>. It also houses the oldest Catholic school for elementary education in Puerto Rico, the Colegio de P\xc3\xa1rvulos, built in 1865.\n</p><p>The oldest parts of the district of Old San Juan remain partly enclosed by massive walls. Several defensive structures and notable <a href="/wiki/Fort" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort">forts</a>, such as the emblematic <a href="/wiki/Fort_San_Felipe_del_Morro" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort San Felipe del Morro">Fort San Felipe del Morro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Castillo_San_Crist%C3%B3bal_(San_Juan)" title="Castillo San Crist\xc3\xb3bal (San Juan)">Fort San Crist\xc3\xb3bal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/El_Palacio_de_Santa_Catalina" class="mw-redirect" title="El Palacio de Santa Catalina">El Palacio de Santa Catalina</a>, also known as <a href="/wiki/La_Fortaleza" title="La Fortaleza">La Fortaleza</a>, acted as the primary defenses of the settlement which was subjected to numerous attacks. <a href="/wiki/La_Fortaleza" title="La Fortaleza">La Fortaleza</a> continues to serve also as the executive mansion for the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Governor of Puerto Rico">governor of Puerto Rico</a>. Many of the historic fortifications are part of <a href="/wiki/San_Juan_National_Historic_Site" title="San Juan National Historic Site">San Juan National Historic Site</a>.\n</p><p>During the 1940s, sections of Old San Juan fell into disrepair, and many renovation plans were suggested. There was even a strong push to develop Old San Juan as a "small <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>". Strict remodeling codes were implemented to prevent new constructions from affecting the common colonial Spanish architectural themes of the old city. When a project proposal suggested that the old Carmelite Convent in San Juan be demolished to erect a new hotel, the Institute had the building declared as a historic building, and then asked that it be converted to a hotel in a renewed facility. This was what became the <i>Hotel El Convento</i> in Old San Juan. The paradigm to reconstruct and renovate the old city and revitalize it has been followed by other cities in the Americas, particularly <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">Havana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lima" title="Lima">Lima</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cartagena_de_Indias" class="mw-redirect" title="Cartagena de Indias">Cartagena de Indias</a>.\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg/220px-Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg/330px-Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg/440px-Parque_de_Bombas_-_Ponce_Puerto_Rico.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3768" data-file-height="2491" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Parque_de_Bombas" title="Parque de Bombas">Parque de Bombas</a>, a landmark of <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce</a>, a former fire station built in 1882.</figcaption></figure>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Ponce_Creole" title="Ponce Creole">Ponce Creole</a> is a unique <a href="/wiki/Architectural_style" title="Architectural style">architectural style</a> created in <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce, Puerto Rico</a>, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This style of Puerto Rican buildings is found predominantly in residential homes in Ponce that developed between 1895 and 1920. Ponce Creole architecture borrows heavily from the traditions of France, Spain and the Caribbean vernacular to create houses that were especially built to withstand the hot and dry climate of the region, and to take advantage of the sun and sea breezes characteristic of the southern Puerto Rico\'s <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a> coast.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is a blend of wood and masonry, incorporating architectural elements of other styles, from <a href="/wiki/Classical_revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Classical revival">Classical revival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Revival">Spanish Revival</a> to <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Arts">Arts</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_art" title="Puerto Rican art">Puerto Rican art</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_(Puerto_Rican,_1751-1809)._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez,_ca._1796..jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg/170px-Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg/255px-Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg/340px-Jos%C3%A9_Campeche_%28Puerto_Rican%2C_1751-1809%29._Do%C3%B1a_Mar%C3%ADa_de_los_Dolores_Guti%C3%A9rrez_del_Mazo_y_P%C3%A9rez%2C_ca._1796..jpg 2x" data-file-width="1228" data-file-height="1536" /></a><figcaption>Mar\xc3\xada de los Dolores Guti\xc3\xa9rrez del Mazo, in colonial Puerto Rico, in 1796, by the mulatto Rococo painter <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Campeche" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 Campeche">Jos\xc3\xa9 Campeche</a>. Painting currently housed in the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Museum" title="Brooklyn Museum">Brooklyn Museum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rican art reflects many influences, much from its ethnically diverse background. A form of <a href="/wiki/Folk_art" title="Folk art">folk art</a>, called <i>santos</i> evolved from the Catholic Church\'s use of <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">sculptures</a> to convert indigenous Puerto Ricans to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>. <i>Santos</i> depict figures of saints and other religious icons and are made from native wood, clay, and stone. After shaping simple, they are often finished by painting them in vivid colors. <i>Santos</i> vary in size, with the smallest examples around eight inches tall and the largest about twenty inches tall. Traditionally, santos were seen as messengers between the earth and Heaven. As such, they occupied a special place on household <a href="/wiki/Altar" title="Altar">altars</a>, where people prayed to them, asked for help, or tried to summon their protection.\n</p><p>Also popular, <i>caretas</i> or <i>vejigantes</i> are masks worn during <a href="/wiki/Carnival" title="Carnival">carnivals</a>. Similar masks signifying evil spirits were used in both Spain and Africa, though for different purposes. The Spanish used their masks to frighten lapsed <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> into returning to the church, while tribal Africans used them as protection from the evil spirits they represented. True to their historic origins, Puerto Rican <i>caretas</i> always bear at least several horns and fangs. While usually constructed of <a href="/wiki/Papier-m%C3%A2ch%C3%A9" title="Papier-m\xc3\xa2ch\xc3\xa9">papier-m\xc3\xa2ch\xc3\xa9</a>, coconut shells and fine metal screening are sometimes used as well. Red and black were the typical colors for <i>caretas</i> but their palette has expanded to include a wide variety of bright hues and patterns.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature">Literature</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_literature" title="Puerto Rican literature">Puerto Rican literature</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg/170px-Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="231" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="247" data-file-height="335" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Mar%C3%ADa_de_Hostos" title="Eugenio Mar\xc3\xada de Hostos">Eugenio Mar\xc3\xada de Hostos</a></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rican literature evolved from the art of <a href="/wiki/Oral_literature" title="Oral literature">oral story telling</a> to its present-day status. Written works by the native islanders of Puerto Rico were prohibited and repressed by the Spanish colonial government. Only those who were commissioned by the Spanish Crown to document the chronological history of the island were allowed to write. <a href="/wiki/Diego_de_Torres_Vargas" title="Diego de Torres Vargas">Diego de Torres Vargas</a> was allowed to circumvent this strict prohibition and in 1647 wrote <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Descripci\xc3\xb3n de la Ciudad e Isla de Puerto Rico</i></span> ("Description of the Island and City of Puerto Rico"). This historical book was the first to make a detailed geographic description of the island.<sup id="cite_ref-DT_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DT-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Some of Puerto Rico\'s earliest writers were influenced by the teachings of <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Cordero_(educator)" title="Rafael Cordero (educator)">Rafael Cordero</a>. Among these was <a href="/wiki/Manuel_A._Alonso" class="mw-redirect" title="Manuel A. Alonso">Manuel A. Alonso</a>, the first Puerto Rican writer of notable importance. In 1849 he published <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">El G\xc3\xadbaro</i></span>, a collection of verses whose main themes were the poor Puerto Rican country farmer. <a href="/wiki/Eugenio_Mar%C3%ADa_de_Hostos" title="Eugenio Mar\xc3\xada de Hostos">Eugenio Mar\xc3\xada de Hostos</a> wrote <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">La peregrinaci\xc3\xb3n de Bayo\xc3\xa1n</i></span> in 1863, which used <a href="/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_de_las_Casas" title="Bartolom\xc3\xa9 de las Casas">Bartolom\xc3\xa9 de las Casas</a> as a springboard to reflect on Caribbean identity. After this first novel, Hostos abandoned fiction in favor of the essay which he saw as offering greater possibilities for inspiring social change.\n</p><p>In the late 19th century, with the arrival of the first printing press and the founding of the Royal Academy of Belles Letters, Puerto Rican literature began to flourish. The first writers to express their political views in regard to Spanish colonial rule of the island were journalists. <a href="/wiki/Alejandro_Tapia_y_Rivera" title="Alejandro Tapia y Rivera">Alejandro Tapia y Rivera</a>, also known as the Father of Puerto Rican Literature, ushered in a new age of <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">historiography</a> with the publication of <i>The Historical Library of Puerto Rico</i>. <a href="/wiki/Cayetano_Coll_y_Toste" title="Cayetano Coll y Toste">Cayetano Coll y Toste</a> was another Puerto Rican historian and writer. His work <i>The Indo-Antillano Vocabulary</i> is valuable in understanding the way the <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADnos" class="mw-redirect" title="Ta\xc3\xadnos">Ta\xc3\xadnos</a> lived. <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Zeno_Gand%C3%ADa" title="Manuel Zeno Gand\xc3\xada">Manuel Zeno Gand\xc3\xada</a> in 1894 wrote <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">La Charca</i></span> and talked about the harsh life in the remote and mountainous coffee regions in Puerto Rico. <a href="/wiki/Antonio_S._Pedreira" title="Antonio S. Pedreira">Antonio S. Pedreira</a>, described in his work <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Insularismo</i></span> the cultural survival of the Puerto Rican identity after the American invasion.\n</p><p>With the Puerto Rican diaspora of the 1940s, Puerto Rican literature was greatly influenced by a phenomenon known as the <a href="/wiki/Nuyorican_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuyorican Movement">Nuyorican Movement</a>. Puerto Rican literature continued to flourish, and many Puerto Ricans have since distinguished themselves as authors, journalists, poets, novelists, playwrights, essayists, and screenwriters. The influence of Puerto Rican literature has transcended the boundaries of the island to the U.S. and the rest of the world. Over the past fifty years, significant writers include <a href="/wiki/Ed_Vega" class="mw-redirect" title="Ed Vega">Ed Vega</a> (<a href="/wiki/The_Lamentable_Journey_of_Omaha_Bigelow_into_the_Impenetrable_Loisaida_Jungle" title="The Lamentable Journey of Omaha Bigelow into the Impenetrable Loisaida Jungle">Omaha Bigelow</a>), <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Pi%C3%B1ero" title="Miguel Pi\xc3\xb1ero">Miguel Pi\xc3\xb1ero</a> (<a href="/wiki/Short_Eyes_(play)" title="Short Eyes (play)">Short Eyes</a>), <a href="/wiki/Piri_Thomas" title="Piri Thomas">Piri Thomas</a> (<a href="/wiki/Down_These_Mean_Streets" title="Down These Mean Streets">Down These Mean Streets</a>), <a href="/wiki/Giannina_Braschi" title="Giannina Braschi">Giannina Braschi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Yo-Yo_Boing!" title="Yo-Yo Boing!">Yo-Yo Boing!</a>), <a href="/wiki/Rosario_Ferr%C3%A9" title="Rosario Ferr\xc3\xa9">Rosario Ferrer</a> (Eccentric Neighborhoods). and <a href="/wiki/Esmeralda_Santiago" title="Esmeralda Santiago">Esmeralda Santiago</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/When_I_was_Puerto_Rican" class="mw-redirect" title="When I was Puerto Rican">When I was Puerto Rican</a>).</i><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media">Media</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Media in Puerto Rico">Media in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mass_media" title="Mass media">mass media</a> in Puerto Rico includes local <a href="/wiki/Radio_stations" class="mw-redirect" title="Radio stations">radio stations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_stations" class="mw-redirect" title="Television stations">television stations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Newspapers" class="mw-redirect" title="Newspapers">newspapers</a>, the majority of which are conducted in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>. There are also three stations of the <a href="/wiki/American_Forces_Network" title="American Forces Network">U.S. Armed Forces Radio and Television Service</a>. Newspapers with daily distribution are <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/El_Nuevo_D%C3%ADa" title="El Nuevo D\xc3\xada">El Nuevo D\xc3\xada</a></i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/El_Vocero" title="El Vocero">El Vocero</a></i></span> and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%8Dndice_(newspaper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="\xc3\x8dndice (newspaper) (page does not exist)">\xc3\x8dndice</a></i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Metro_(Puerto_Rico)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metro (Puerto Rico) (page does not exist)">Metro</a></i></span>, and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Primera_Hora_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)">Primera Hora</a></i></span>. <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">El Vocero</i></span> is distributed free of charge, as are <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">\xc3\x8dndice</i></span> and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Metro</i></span>.\n</p><p>Newspapers distributed on a weekly or regional basis include <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Claridad" title="Claridad">Claridad</a></i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/La_Perla_del_Sur" title="La Perla del Sur">La Perla del Sur</a></i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/La_Opini%C3%B3n" title="La Opini\xc3\xb3n">La Opini\xc3\xb3n</a></i></span>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Visi%C3%B3n_(Puerto_Rico)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Visi\xc3\xb3n (Puerto Rico) (page does not exist)">Visi\xc3\xb3n</a></i></span>, and <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Estrella_del_Norte&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="La Estrella del Norte (page does not exist)">La Estrella del Norte</a></i></span>, among others. Several television channels provide local content in the island. These include <a href="/wiki/WIPR-TV" title="WIPR-TV">WIPR-TV</a>, <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es"><a href="/wiki/Telemundo_Puerto_Rico_(TV_channel)" class="mw-redirect" title="Telemundo Puerto Rico (TV channel)">Telemundo</a></i></span>, Univision affiliate <a href="/wiki/WLII-DT" title="WLII-DT">WLII-DT</a> (<span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Teleonce</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/WAPA-TV" title="WAPA-TV">WAPA-TV</a>, and <a href="/wiki/WKAQ-TV" title="WKAQ-TV">WKAQ-TV</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Music">Music</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Music of Puerto Rico">Music of Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><video id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/220px--Bomba-1.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="220" height="124" data-durationhint="114" data-mwtitle="Bomba-1.ogv" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:Bomba-1.ogv"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/Bomba-1.ogv.480p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" data-height="480" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv" type="video/ogg; codecs=&quot;theora, vorbis&quot;" data-width="960" data-height="540" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/Bomba-1.ogv.m3u8" type="application/vnd.apple.mpegurl" data-transcodekey="m3u8" data-width="0" data-height="0" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/Bomba-1.ogv.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/Bomba-1.ogv.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp8, vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/Bomba-1.ogv.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" /></video></span><figcaption>A dancer performs typical <i><a href="/wiki/Bomba_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Bomba (Puerto Rico)">bomba</a></i> choreography.</figcaption></figure>\n<p>The music of Puerto Rico has evolved as a heterogeneous and dynamic product of diverse cultural resources. The most conspicuous musical sources have been Spain and West Africa, although many aspects of Puerto Rican music reflect origins elsewhere in Europe and the Caribbean and, over the last century, from the U.S. Puerto Rican music culture today comprises a wide and rich variety of genres, ranging from indigenous genres like <a href="/wiki/Bomba_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Bomba (Puerto Rico)">bomba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plena" title="Plena">plena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aguinaldo_(music)" title="Aguinaldo (music)">aguinaldo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Danza" title="Danza">danza</a> and the popular  <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa</a> to recent hybrids like <a href="/wiki/Reggaeton" title="Reggaeton">reggaeton</a>.\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has some national instruments, like the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_cuatro" title="Puerto Rican cuatro">cuatro</a> (Spanish for "four"). The cuatro is a local instrument that was made by the "Jibaro" or people from the mountains. Originally, the Cuatro consisted of four steel strings, hence its name, but currently the Cuatro consists of five double steel strings. It is easily confused with a guitar, even by locals. When held upright, from right to left, the strings are G, D, A, E, B.\n</p><p>In the realm of <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a>, the island hosts two main orchestras, the <a href="/wiki/Orquesta_Sinf%C3%B3nica_de_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Orquesta Sinf\xc3\xb3nica de Puerto Rico">Orquesta Sinf\xc3\xb3nica de Puerto Rico</a> and the Orquesta Filarm\xc3\xb3nica de Puerto Rico. The <a href="/wiki/Casals_Festival" title="Casals Festival">Casals Festival</a> takes place annually in San Juan, drawing in classical musicians from around the world.\n</p><p>With respect to <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a>, the legendary Puerto Rican tenor <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Paoli" title="Antonio Paoli">Antonio Paoli</a> was so celebrated, that he performed private recitals for <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_X" title="Pope Pius X">Pope Pius X</a> and Tsar <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II of Russia</a>. In 1907, Paoli was the first operatic artist in world history to record an entire opera \xe2\x80\x93 when he participated in a performance of <i><a href="/wiki/Pagliacci" title="Pagliacci">Pagliacci</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Ruggiero_Leoncavallo" class="mw-redirect" title="Ruggiero Leoncavallo">Ruggiero Leoncavallo</a> in <a href="/wiki/Milan,_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Milan, Italy">Milan, Italy</a>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Philately">Philately</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_on_stamps" title="Puerto Rico on stamps">Puerto Rico on stamps</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg/170px-San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="267" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e3/San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="184" data-file-height="289" /></a><figcaption>San Juan 450th 1971 issue, depicting one of the <a href="/wiki/File:Lookout_Station.JPG" title="File:Lookout Station.JPG">garitas</a> of El Morro</figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rico has been commemorated on four U.S. postal stamps. Insular Territories were commemorated in 1937, the third stamp honored Puerto Rico featuring \'<a href="/wiki/La_Fortaleza" title="La Fortaleza">La Fortaleza</a>\', the Spanish Governor\'s Palace.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The first free election for governor of the U.S. territory of Puerto Rico was honored on 27 April 1949, at San Juan, Puerto Rico. \'Inauguration\' on the 3-cent stamp refers to the election of <a href="/wiki/Luis_Mu%C3%B1oz_Mar%C3%ADn" title="Luis Mu\xc3\xb1oz Mar\xc3\xadn">Luis Mu\xc3\xb1oz Mar\xc3\xadn</a>, the first democratically elected governor of Puerto Rico.<sup id="cite_ref-Puerto_Rico_Election_Issue_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Puerto_Rico_Election_Issue-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> San Juan, Puerto Rico was commemorated with an 8-cent stamp on its 450th anniversary issued 12 September 1971, featuring a sentry box from <a href="/wiki/Castillo_San_Felipe_del_Morro" title="Castillo San Felipe del Morro">Castillo San Felipe del Morro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the "Flags of our nation series" 2008\xe2\x80\x932012, of the fifty-five, five territorial flags were featured. Forever stamps included the <a href="/wiki/Flags_of_Puerto_Rico" class="mw-redirect" title="Flags of Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico Flag</a> illustrated by a bird issued 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cuisine">Cuisine</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_cuisine" title="Puerto Rican cuisine">Puerto Rican cuisine</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Arroz_con_gandules.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Arroz_con_gandules.jpg/220px-Arroz_con_gandules.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Arroz_con_gandules.jpg/330px-Arroz_con_gandules.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Arroz_con_gandules.jpg/440px-Arroz_con_gandules.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Arroz_con_gandules" title="Arroz con gandules">Arroz con gandules</a>, widely regarded as "Puerto Rico\'s national dish"<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>\n<p>Puerto Rican cuisine has its roots in the cooking traditions and practices of Europe (Spain), Africa and the native <a href="/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno" title="Ta\xc3\xadno">Ta\xc3\xadnos</a>. Basic ingredients include <a href="/wiki/Grain" title="Grain">grains</a> and <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herb" title="Herb">herbs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spice" title="Spice">spices</a>, starchy tropical <a href="/wiki/Tuber" title="Tuber">tubers</a>, vegetables, meat and poultry, seafood and shellfish, and fruits. Main dishes include <i><a href="/wiki/Mofongo" title="Mofongo">mofongo</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Arroz_con_gandules" title="Arroz con gandules">arroz con gandules</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pasteles" title="Pasteles">pasteles</a></i>, and <a href="/wiki/Pig_roast" title="Pig roast">pig roast</a> (or <a href="/wiki/Suckling_pig" title="Suckling pig">lech\xc3\xb3n</a>). Beverages include <i><a href="/wiki/Mauby" title="Mauby">mav\xc3\xad</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Pi%C3%B1a_colada" title="Pi\xc3\xb1a colada">pi\xc3\xb1a colada</a></i>. Desserts include flan, <i>arroz con dulce</i> (sweet <a href="/wiki/Rice_pudding" title="Rice pudding">rice pudding</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Piragua_(food)" title="Piragua (food)">piraguas</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Brazo_gitano" class="mw-redirect" title="Brazo gitano">brazo gitanos</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Tembleque" title="Tembleque">tembleque</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Polvor%C3%B3n" title="Polvor\xc3\xb3n">polvorones</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Dulce_de_leche" title="Dulce de leche">dulce de leche</a></i>.\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Sports">Sports</h3></div>\n<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_Puerto_Rico" title="Sports in Puerto Rico">Sports in Puerto Rico</a></div>\n<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg/220px-DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg/330px-DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg/440px-DR_vs_PR._World_Baseball_Classic.jpg 2x" data-file-width="612" data-file-height="612" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/2013_World_Baseball_Classic_championship" title="2013 World Baseball Classic championship">2013 World Baseball Classic championship</a> between <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_baseball_team" title="Puerto Rico national baseball team">Puerto Rico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic_national_baseball_team" title="Dominican Republic national baseball team">Dominican Republic</a>, 20 March 2013</figcaption></figure>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">Baseball</a> was one of the first sports to gain widespread popularity in Puerto Rico. The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Baseball_League" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico Baseball League">Puerto Rico Baseball League</a> serves as the only active professional league, operating as a winter league. No <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> franchise or affiliate plays in Puerto Rico; however, San Juan hosted the <a href="/wiki/Montreal_Expos" title="Montreal Expos">Montreal Expos</a> for several series in 2003 and 2004 before they moved to Washington, D.C., and became the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Nationals" title="Washington Nationals">Washington Nationals</a>.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_baseball_team" title="Puerto Rico national baseball team">Puerto Rico national baseball team</a> has participated in the <a href="/wiki/World_Cup_of_Baseball" class="mw-redirect" title="World Cup of Baseball">World Cup of Baseball</a> winning one gold (1951), four silver and four bronze medals, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Series" title="Caribbean Series">Caribbean Series</a> (winning fourteen times) and the <a href="/wiki/World_Baseball_Classic" title="World Baseball Classic">World Baseball Classic</a>. In <span class="nowrap">March 2006</span>, San Juan\'s <a href="/wiki/Hiram_Bithorn_Stadium" title="Hiram Bithorn Stadium">Hiram Bithorn Stadium</a> hosted the opening round as well as the second round of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/World_Baseball_Classic" title="World Baseball Classic">World Baseball Classic</a>. Puerto Rican baseball players include <a href="/wiki/Hall_of_Fame" class="mw-redirect" title="Hall of Fame">Hall of Famers</a> <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Clemente" title="Roberto Clemente">Roberto Clemente</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Cepeda" title="Orlando Cepeda">Orlando Cepeda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roberto_Alomar" title="Roberto Alomar">Roberto Alomar</a>, enshrined in 1973, 1999, and 2011 respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">Boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a> are considered popular sports as well. <a href="/wiki/Wilfredo_G%C3%B3mez" title="Wilfredo G\xc3\xb3mez">Wilfredo G\xc3\xb3mez</a> and <a href="/wiki/McWilliams_Arroyo" title="McWilliams Arroyo">McWilliams Arroyo</a> have won their respective divisions at the <a href="/wiki/World_Amateur_Boxing_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="World Amateur Boxing Championships">World Amateur Boxing Championships</a>. Other medalists include <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Pedraza_(boxer)" title="Jos\xc3\xa9 Pedraza (boxer)">Jos\xc3\xa9 Pedraza</a>, who holds a silver medal, and three boxers who finished in third place, Jos\xc3\xa9 Luis Vell\xc3\xb3n, <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Dieppa" title="Nelson Dieppa">Nelson Dieppa</a> and <a href="/wiki/McJoe_Arroyo" title="McJoe Arroyo">McJoe Arroyo</a>. In the professional circuit, Puerto Rico has the third-most <a href="/wiki/List_of_Puerto_Rican_boxing_world_champions" title="List of Puerto Rican boxing world champions">boxing world champions</a> and it is the global leader in champions per capita. These include <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Cotto" title="Miguel Cotto">Miguel Cotto</a>, <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Trinidad" title="F\xc3\xa9lix Trinidad">F\xc3\xa9lix Trinidad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wilfred_Ben%C3%ADtez" title="Wilfred Ben\xc3\xadtez">Wilfred Ben\xc3\xadtez</a> and G\xc3\xb3mez among others.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Puerto Rico national basketball team">Puerto Rico national basketball team</a> joined the <a href="/wiki/International_Basketball_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="International Basketball Federation">International Basketball Federation</a> in 1957. Since then, it has won more than 30 medals in international competitions, including gold in three <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Americas Championship">FIBA Americas Championships</a> and the 1994 <a href="/wiki/Goodwill_Games" title="Goodwill Games">Goodwill Games</a> 8 August 2004, became a landmark date for the team when it became the first team to defeat the <a href="/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_basketball_team" title="United States men&#39;s national basketball team">United States</a> in an Olympic tournament since the integration of <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a> players. Winning the inaugural game with scores of 92\xe2\x80\x9373 as part of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> organized in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>, Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baloncesto_Superior_Nacional" title="Baloncesto Superior Nacional">Baloncesto Superior Nacional</a> acts as the top-level professional basketball league in Puerto Rico and has experienced success since its beginning in 1930.\n</p>\n<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Orangestarsultra.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Orangestarsultra.jpg/220px-Orangestarsultra.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Orangestarsultra.jpg/330px-Orangestarsultra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Orangestarsultra.jpg/440px-Orangestarsultra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Islanders" title="Puerto Rico Islanders">Puerto Rico Islanders</a> fans at a soccer game</figcaption></figure>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_football_team" title="Puerto Rico national football team">Puerto Rico</a> is also a member of <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> and <a href="/wiki/CONCACAF" title="CONCACAF">CONCACAF</a>. In 2008, the archipelago\'s first unified league, the <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Soccer_League" title="Puerto Rico Soccer League">Puerto Rico Soccer League</a>, was established.\n</p><p>Other sports include <a href="/wiki/Professional_wrestling" title="Professional wrestling">professional wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Road_running" title="Road running">road running</a>. The <a href="/wiki/World_Wrestling_Council" title="World Wrestling Council">World Wrestling Council</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_Wrestling_Association_(Puerto_Rico)" title="International Wrestling Association (Puerto Rico)">International Wrestling Association</a> are the largest wrestling promotions in the main island. The <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Best_10K" title="World&#39;s Best 10K">World\'s Best 10K</a>, held annually in San Juan, has been ranked among the 20 most competitive races globally. The "Puerto Rico All Stars" team, which has won twelve world championships in unicycle basketball.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Organized <a href="/wiki/Streetball" title="Streetball">Streetball</a> has gathered some exposition, with teams like "Puerto Rico Street Ball" competing against established organizations including the <a href="/wiki/Arecibo_Captains" class="mw-redirect" title="Arecibo Captains">Capitanes de Arecibo</a> and <a href="/wiki/AND1" title="AND1">AND1</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/AND1_Mixtape_Tour" class="mw-redirect" title="AND1 Mixtape Tour">Mixtape Tour Team</a>. Six years after the first visit, AND1 returned as part of their renamed Live Tour, losing to the Puerto Rico Streetballers.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Consequently, practitioners of this style have earned participation in international teams, including <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Melendez" class="mw-redirect" title="Orlando Melendez">Orlando "El Gato" Mel\xc3\xa9ndez</a>, who became the first Puerto Rican born athlete to play for the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Globetrotters" title="Harlem Globetrotters">Harlem Globetrotters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p><p>Puerto Rico has representation in all international competitions including the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Summer Olympics">Summer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Winter Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pan_American_Games" title="Pan American Games">Pan American Games</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_World_Series" class="mw-redirect" title="Caribbean World Series">Caribbean World Series</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games" title="Central American and Caribbean Games">Central American and Caribbean Games</a>. Puerto Rico hosted the Pan Am Games in 1979 (officially in San Juan), and The <a href="/wiki/Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games" title="Central American and Caribbean Games">Central American and Caribbean Games</a> were hosted in <a href="/wiki/1993_Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games" title="1993 Central American and Caribbean Games">1993</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico" title="Ponce, Puerto Rico">Ponce</a> and in <a href="/wiki/2010_Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games" title="2010 Central American and Caribbean Games">2010</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez" class="mw-redirect" title="Mayag\xc3\xbcez">Mayag\xc3\xbcez</a>.\n</p><p>Puerto Rican athletes have won ten medals in Olympic competition (two gold, two silver, six bronze), the first one in 1948 by boxer <a href="/wiki/Juan_Evangelista_Venegas" title="Juan Evangelista Venegas">Juan Evangelista Venegas</a>. <a href="/wiki/Monica_Puig" title="Monica Puig">Monica Puig</a> won the first gold medal for Puerto Rico in the Olympic Games by winning the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics#Medal_events" title="Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics">Women\'s Tennis singles title in Rio 2016</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2></div>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Puerto_Rico-related_articles" class="mw-redirect" title="Index of Puerto Rico-related articles">Index of Puerto Rico-related articles</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Outline of Puerto Rico">Outline of Puerto Rico</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Stateside_Puerto_Ricans" title="Stateside Puerto Ricans">Stateside Puerto Ricans</a>, living on mainland</li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Puerto_Rico" title="List of islands of Puerto Rico">List of islands of Puerto Rico</a></li></ul>\n<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239543626">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">\n<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Despite being under the sovereignty of the United States since 1898, Puerto Rico has not been fully <a href="/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States#Incorporated_vs._unincorporated_territories" title="Territories of the United States">incorporated</a> into the country for constitutional purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> See the page for the <a href="/wiki/Insular_Cases#Background" title="Insular Cases">Insular Cases</a> for more information.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-commonwealth-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-commonwealth_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-commonwealth_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">The definition of <i><a href="/wiki/Commonwealth" title="Commonwealth">Commonwealth</a></i> according to <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">U.S. State Department</a> policy (as codified in the department\'s <i><a href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs_Manual" title="Foreign Affairs Manual">Foreign Affairs Manual</a></i>) reads: "The term \'Commonwealth\' does not describe or provide for any specific political status or relationship."<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The term <i>boricua</i> is gender-neutral, whereas the terms <i>puertorrique\xc3\xb1o</i>, <i>borinque\xc3\xb1o</i>, <i>borincano</i>, and <i>puertorro</i> are male-specific when ending in \xc2\xabo\xc2\xbb and female-specific when ending in \xc2\xaba\xc2\xbb.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The term <i>puertorro -a</i> is used <a href="/wiki/Popular_culture" title="Popular culture">popularly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colloquialism" title="Colloquialism">spontaneously</a>, and <a href="/wiki/High_culture" title="High culture">politely</a> to refer to Puerto Ricans or Puerto Rico. It is occasionally mistaken for a <a href="/wiki/Pejorative" title="Pejorative">pejorative</a>, but the term is not considered offensive by Puerto Ricans. It has been most famously used by Puerto Rican musicians, including <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Valent%C3%ADn" title="Bobby Valent\xc3\xadn">Bobby Valent\xc3\xadn</a> in his song <i>Soy Boricua</i> (1972), <a href="/wiki/Andy_Monta%C3%B1ez" title="Andy Monta\xc3\xb1ez">Andy Monta\xc3\xb1ez</a> in <i>En Mi Puertorro</i> (2006), and <a href="/wiki/Bad_Bunny" title="Bad Bunny">Bad Bunny</a> in <i>ACHO PR</i> (2023).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-area-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-area_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> The area of the main island of Puerto Rico is 5,325 m\xc2\xb2 (13,792 km\xc2\xb2). The <a href="/wiki/Land" title="Land">land</a> and <a href="/wiki/Internal_waters" title="Internal waters">internal coastal water</a> area is 3,513 m\xc2\xb2 (9,100 km\xc2\xb2), with land covering 3,424 m\xc2\xb2 (8,868 km\xc2\xb2) and internal costal waters 89 m\xc2\xb2 (232 km\xc2\xb2). Its <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">territorial waters</a> stretch for 1,812 m\xc2\xb2 (4,692 km\xc2\xb2).<sup id="cite_ref-Geography_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The island of Vieques has a total land area of 51 m\xc2\xb2 (132 km\xc2\xb2),<sup id="cite_ref-Geography23_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography23-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Mona has 22 m\xc2\xb2 (56 km\xc2\xb2),<sup id="cite_ref-Geography24_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography24-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Culebra has 12 m\xc2\xb2 (31 km\xc2\xb2),<sup id="cite_ref-Geography25_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography25-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Caja de Muertos has 0.62 m\xc2\xb2 (1.62 km\xc2\xb2),<sup id="cite_ref-Geography26_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography26-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and Desecheo has 0.56 m\xc2\xb2 (1.45 km\xc2\xb2).<sup id="cite_ref-Geography27_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography27-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In total, the entire archipelago of Puerto Rico has a land area of about 3,510 m\xc2\xb2 (9,090 km\xc2\xb2) and an <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone#United_States" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> of 68,605 m\xc2\xb2 (177,327 km\xc2\xb2).<sup id="cite_ref-Geography22_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geography22-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> See <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Geography of Puerto Rico">Geography of Puerto Rico</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-100x35-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100x35_19-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Puerto Rico, the main island of the archipelago of the same name, is 178 kilometers long (110 <a href="/wiki/Mile" title="Mile">statute miles</a>; 96 <a href="/wiki/Nautical_mile" title="Nautical mile">nautical miles</a>) and 65 kilometers wide (40 statute miles; 35 nautical miles). Boricuas often refer to Puerto Rico as <i>100x35</i> (<a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>: <i>100por35</i>), a direct reference to the island\'s size in nautical miles. Various Puerto Rican singers have used the term, including <a href="/wiki/Farruko" title="Farruko">Farruko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Cap%C3%B3" title="Pedro Cap\xc3\xb3">Pedro Cap\xc3\xb3</a> in their song <i>J\xc3\xadbaro</i> (2021).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-peakk-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-peakk_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Cerro_de_Punta" title="Cerro de Punta">Cerro de Punta</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_Central_(Puerto_Rico)" title="Cordillera Central (Puerto Rico)">Cordillera Central</a> mountain range is the highest elevation in Puerto Rico.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-pop-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-pop_22-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Puerto Rico is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Caribbean_countries_by_population#Table" title="List of Caribbean countries by population">4th most populated</a> island in the Caribbean, <a href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anexo:Islas_por_superficie_y_poblaci%C3%B3n#Mayores_islas_del_mundo" class="extiw" title="es:Anexo:Islas por superficie y poblaci\xc3\xb3n">27th most populated</a> island in the world, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population#Sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">136th most populated</a> country or dependency in the world.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Pronunciation:\n<ul><li><span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">English: </span><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/\xcb\x8c/: secondary stress follows">\xcb\x8c</span><span title="&#39;p&#39; in &#39;pie&#39;">p</span><span title="/\xc9\x94\xcb\x90r/: &#39;ar&#39; in &#39;war&#39;">\xc9\x94\xcb\x90r</span><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span><span title="/\xc9\x99/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">\xc9\x99</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/\xcb\x88/: primary stress follows">\xcb\x88</span><span title="&#39;r&#39; in &#39;rye&#39;">r</span><span title="/i\xcb\x90/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">i\xcb\x90</span><span title="&#39;k&#39; in &#39;kind&#39;">k</span><span title="/o\xca\x8a/: &#39;o&#39; in &#39;code&#39;">o\xca\x8a</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/\xcb\x8c/: secondary stress follows">\xcb\x8c</span><span title="&#39;p&#39; in &#39;pie&#39;">p</span><span title="&#39;w&#39; in &#39;wind&#39;">w</span><span title="/\xc9\x9b\xc9\x99r/: &#39;are&#39; in &#39;bare&#39;">\xc9\x9b\xc9\x99r</span><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span><span title="/\xc9\x99/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">\xc9\x99</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span>-,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="&#39;t&#39; in &#39;tie&#39;">t</span><span title="/o\xca\x8a/: &#39;o&#39; in &#39;code&#39;">o\xca\x8a</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span>-/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">POR</span>-t\xc9\x99 <span style="font-size:90%">REE</span>-koh, <span style="font-size:90%">PWAIR</span>-t\xc9\x99 -&#8288;, -&#8288;toh -&#8288;</i></a>;</li>\n<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1177148991"><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">Spanish:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="es-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">&#91;\xcb\x88pwe\xc9\xbeto<span class="wrap"> </span>\xcb\x88riko&#93;</a></span>, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1177148991"><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">locally (in rural areas)</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">&#91;\xcb\x88pwelto<span class="wrap"> </span>\xcb\x88\xcf\x87iko,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span class="wrap"> </span>\xcb\x88\xca\x80\xcc\xa5iko&#93;</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Taino_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Taino language">Taino</a>: <i lang="tnq">Borik\xc3\xa9n</i> or <span title="Taino-language text"><i lang="tnq">Borinquen</i></span></li></ul>\n</span></li>\n<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Spanish: <i lang="es">Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico</i>, <small><abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr>&#8201;</small>&#39;Free Associated State of Puerto Rico&#39;</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See the <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Political status of Puerto Rico">Political status of Puerto Rico</a> article for more information.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Proyecto Sal\xc3\xb3n Hogar (in Spanish) "<span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Los espa\xc3\xb1oles le cambiaron el nombre de Borik\xc3\xa9n a San Juan Bautista y a la capital le llamaron Ciudad de Puerto Rico. Con los a\xc3\xb1os, Ciudad de Puerto Rico pas\xc3\xb3 a ser San Juan, y San Juan Bautista pas\xc3\xb3 a ser Puerto Rico.</i></span>"<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 1932, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Congress">U.S. Congress</a> officially back-corrected the former <a href="/wiki/Anglicization" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglicization">Anglicization</a> of <i>Porto Rico</i> into the Spanish name <i>Puerto Rico</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It had been using the former spelling in its legislative and judicial records since it acquired the archipelago. Patricia Gherovici states that both <i>Porto Rico</i> and <i>Puerto Rico</i> were used interchangeably in the news media and documentation before, during, and after the U.S. conquest of the island in 1898. The <i>Porto</i> spelling, for instance, was used in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1898)" title="Treaty of Paris (1898)">Treaty of Paris</a>, but <i>Puerto</i> was used by <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> that same year. Nancy Morris clarifies that "a curious oversight in the drafting of the <a href="/wiki/Foraker_Act" title="Foraker Act">Foraker Act</a> caused the name of the island to be officially misspelled".<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Gervasio Luis Garcia traces the Anglicized spelling to a <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Geographic (magazine)">National Geographic</a></i> article from 1899, after which the spelling was kept by many agencies and entities because of the ethnic and linguistic pride of the English-speaking citizens of the American mainland.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-72">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Text of <i>Ortega v. Lara</i>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_cases,_volume_202" title="List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 202">202</a>&#32;<a href="/wiki/United_States_Reports" title="United States Reports">U.S.</a> 339, 342&#32;(1906) is available from:<span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/202/339">Cornell</a><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/202/339.html">Findlaw</a><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/202/339/">Justia</a><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://openjurist.org/202/us/339">OpenJurist</a><span class="nowrap">&#160;</span> </span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-180">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">pr.gov (in Spanish) "La manufactura es el sector principal de la econom\xc3\xada de Puerto Rico."<sup id="cite_ref-manufacturing-by-pr.gov_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-manufacturing-by-pr.gov-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-181"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-181">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">pr.gov (in Spanish) "Algunas de las industrias m\xc3\xa1s destacadas dentro del sector de la manufactura son: las farmac\xc3\xa9uticas, los textiles, los petroqu\xc3\xadmicos, las computadoras, la electr\xc3\xb3nica y las compa\xc3\xb1\xc3\xadas dedicadas a la manufactura de instrumentos m\xc3\xa9dicos y cient\xc3\xadficos, entre otros."<sup id="cite_ref-manufacturing-by-pr.gov_49-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-manufacturing-by-pr.gov-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-186">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Torrech San Inocencio (2011; in Spanish) "Con los m\xc3\xa1s de $1,500 millones anuales que recibimos en asistencia federal para alimentos podr\xc3\xadamos desarrollar una industria alimentaria autosuficiente en Puerto Rico."<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span que la propuesta del Gobernador para hacer cambios en la composici\xc3\xb3n del organismo institucionaliza la intervenci\xc3\xb3n pol\xc3\xadtico partidista en la corporaci\xc3\xb3n p\xc3\xbablica y la convierte en una agencia del Ejecutivo.."<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>170<span (2013; in Spanish) "Aunque Puerto Rico mueve entre el sector p\xc3\xbablico y privado $15 billones en el \xc3\xa1rea de salud, las deficiencias en el sistema todav\xc3\xada no alcanzan un nivel de eficiencia \xc3\xb3ptimo."<sup id="cite_ref-el-vocero-inefficient-health-2013_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-el-vocero-inefficient-health-2013-189"><span Al Gobierno le falt\xc3\xb3 creatividad, innovaci\xc3\xb3n y rapidez en la creaci\xc3\xb3n de un nuevo modelo econ\xc3\xb3mico que sustentara nuestra econom\xc3\xada. Tras la eliminaci\xc3\xb3n de la Secci\xc3\xb3n 936, debimos ser proactivos, y no lo fuimos."<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-199">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Quintero (2013; in Spanish) "Los indicadores de una econom\xc3\xada d\xc3\xa9bil son muchos, y la econom\xc3\xada en Puerto Rico est\xc3\xa1 sumamente debilitada, seg\xc3\xban lo evidencian la tasa de desempleo (13.5%), los altos niveles de pobreza (41.7%), los altos niveles de quiebra y la p\xc3\xa9rdida poblacional."<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-212"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-212">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Walsh (2013) "In each of the last six years, Puerto Rico sold hundreds of millions of dollars of new bonds just to meet payments on its older, outstanding bonds \xe2\x80\x93 a red flag. It also sold $2.5&#160;billion worth of bonds to raise cash for its troubled pension system \xe2\x80\x93 a risky practice \xe2\x80\x93 and it sold still more long-term bonds to cover its yearly budget deficits."<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-215">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">PRGDB "Financial Information and Operating Data Report to 18 October 2013" p. 142<sup id="cite_ref-gdb-report-2013_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gdb-report-2013-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-221">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">MRGI (2008) "Many female migrants leave their families behind due to the risk of illegal travel and the high cost of living in Puerto Rico."<sup id="cite_ref-refworld.org_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-refworld.org-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">FRBNY (2011) "...home values vary considerably across municipios: for the metro area overall, the median value of owner-occupied homes was estimated at $126,000 (based on data for 2007\xe2\x80\x9309), but these medians ranged from $214,000 in Guaynabo to around $100,000 in some of the outlying municipios. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 October</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Political+Status+of+Puerto+Rico%3A+Background%2C+Options%2C+and+Issues+in+the+109th+Congress&amp;rft.pub=Congressional+Research+Service&amp;rft.date=2005-05-25&amp;rft.au=Keith+Bea&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ffas.org%2Fsgp%2Fcrs%2Frow%2FRL32933.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APuerto+Rico" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">U.S. Const. art. IV, \xc2\xa7 3, cl. 2 ("The Congress shall have Power to dispose of and make all needful Rules and Regulations respecting the Territory or other Property belonging to the United States&#160;...").</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Downes_v._Bidwell" title="Downes v. Bidwell">Downes v. Bidwell</a>, 182 U.S. 244, 261 (1901), commenting on an earlier Supreme Court decision, Loughborough v. Blake, 18 U.S. (5 Wheat.) 317 (1820); Rasmussen v. United States, 197 U.S. 516, 529\xe2\x80\x93530, 536 (1905)(concurring opinions of Justices Harlan and Brown), that once the Constitution has been extended to an area, its coverage is irrevocable; <a href="/wiki/Boumediene_v._Bush" title="Boumediene v. Bush">Boumediene v. Bush</a> \xe2\x80\x93 That where the Constitution has been once formally extended by Congress to territories, neither Congress nor the territorial legislature can enact laws inconsistent therewith. The Constitution grants Congress and the President the power to acquire, dispose of, and govern territory, not the power to decide when and where its terms apply.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>The Louisiana Purchase and American Expansion: 1803\xe2\x80\x931898</i>. By Sanford Levinson and Bartholomew H. Sparrow. New York: Rowman &amp; Littlefield Publishers. 2005. pp. 166, 178. "U.S. citizenship was extended to residents of Puerto Rico by virtue of the Jones Act, chap. 190, 39 Stat. 951 (1971)(codified at 48 U.S.C. \xc2\xa7 731 (1987)")</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Constitutional_Topic:_Citizenship-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Constitutional_Topic:_Citizenship_144-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.usconstitution.net/consttop_citi.html">"Constitutional Topic: Citizenship"</a>. "Historical Accumulation of Nonindigenous Forest Pests in the Continental United States". <i><a href="/wiki/BioScience" title="BioScience">BioScience</a></i>. <b>60</b> (11). <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a> (<a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Biological_Sciences" title="American Institute of Biological Sciences">American Institute of Biological Sciences</a>): 886\xe2\x80\x93897. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1525%2Fbio.2010.60.11.5">10.1525/bio.2010.60.11.5</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1525-3244">1525-3244</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:28154739">28154739</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=BioScience&amp;rft.atitle=Historical+Accumulation+of+Nonindigenous+Forest+Pests+in+the+Continental+United+States&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=11&amp;rft.pages=886-897&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A28154739%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1525-3244&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1525%2Fbio.2010.60.11.5&amp;rft.aulast=Aukema&amp;rft.aufirst=Juliann+E.&amp;rft.au=McCullough%2C+Deborah+G.&amp;rft.au=Von+Holle%2C+Betsy&amp;rft.au=Liebhold%2C+Andrew+M.&amp;rft.au=Britton%2C+Kerry&amp;rft.au=Frankel%2C+Susan+J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APuerto+Rico" class="Z3988"></span></li><li>&#160;&#8226;&#32; USA Today. 2 April 2019. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20191127164315/https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/news/2019/04/02/puerto-rico-breaks-tourism-record-while-rebuilding-hurricane-maria/3346139002/">Archived</a> from the original on 27 November 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 November</span> 2019</span>. <q>Brief power outages still hit occasionally as the government prepares to privatize an aging and poorly maintained grid that was destroyed by the hurricane, and water shortages have hit parts of Puerto Rico\'s north coast since 30 percent of the island is experiencing a moderate drought that is affecting 791,000 of its 3.2 million inhabitants.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Nearly+two+years+after+Hurricane+Maria+devastation%2C+Puerto+Rico+welcomes+record+number+of+tourists&amp;rft.pub=USA+Today&amp;rft.date=2019-04-02&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usatoday.com%2Fstory%2Ftravel%2Fnews%2F2019%2F04%2F02%2Fpuerto-rico-breaks-tourism-record-while-rebuilding-hurricane-maria%2F3346139002%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APuerto+Rico" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.viahero.com/travel-to-puerto-rico/puerto-rico-tourism-update">"Nearly two years after Hurricane Maria devastation, Puerto Rico welcomes record number of tourists"</a>. ViaHero. 2 April 2019. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20191127164436/https://www.viahero.com/travel-to-puerto-rico/puerto-rico-tourism-update">Archived</a> from the original on 27 November 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 October</span> 2019</span>. <q>Almost all of Puerto Rico\'s hotels are open for business. The beaches are ready for swimming and sunbathing, and even remote places to visit like El Yunque rainforest are receiving visitors.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Nearly+two+years+after+Hurricane+Maria+devastation%2C+Puerto+Rico+welcomes+record+number+of+tourists&amp;rft.pub=ViaHero&amp;rft.date=2019-04-02&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.viahero.com%2Ftravel-to-puerto-rico%2Fpuerto-rico-tourism-update&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APuerto+Rico" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-202">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://skift.com/2019/04/24/culture-is-central-in-puerto-ricos-new-marketing-campaign/">"Culture Is Central in Puerto Rico\'s New Marketing Campaign"</a>. Skift. 24 April 2019. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20191127164352/https://skift.com/2019/04/24/culture-is-central-in-puerto-ricos-new-marketing-campaign/">Archived</a> from the original on 27 November 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Reuters. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170217145557/http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/latestnews/2017/01/18/Puerto-Rico-oversight-board-favors-more-time-restructuring-talks">Archived</a> from the original on 17 February 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 February</span> 2017</span>. <q>The bipartisan, seven-member oversight board was created under the federal Puerto Rico rescue law known as PROMESA, passed by the U.S. Congress last year. It is charged with helping the island manage its finances and navigate its way out of the economic jam, including by negotiating restructuring deals with creditors.</q></cite><span Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 February</span> 2017</span>. <q>Puerto Ricans in this statistical profile are people who self-identified as Hispanics of Puerto Rican origin; this means either they themselves were born in Puerto Rico1 or they were born in the 50 U.S. states, the District of Columbia or elsewhere, but trace their family ancestry to Puerto Rico.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Hispanics+of+Puerto+Rican+Origin+in+the+United+States%2C+2013&amp;rft.date=2015-09-15&amp;rft.aulast=L%C3%B3pez&amp;rft.aufirst=Gustavo&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewhispanic.org%2F2015%2F09%2F15%2Fhispanics-of-puerto-rican-origin-in-the-united-states-2013%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APuerto+Rico" class="Z3988"></span></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-289"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-289">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pewforum.org/2014/11/13/religion-in-latin-america/">"Religion in Latin America"</a>. <i>Pew Research</i>.
